title: Climate change: Fossil fuel production set to soar over next decade
writtenTitle: Climate change: Fossil fuel production set to soar over next decade
summary:
The UN says plans by governments to extract fossil fuels up to 2030 are incompatible with keeping global temperatures to safe levels.
A study says coal production will drop but gas will increase over the next 20 years.
The report profiles 15 major production countries including Australia, Russia, Saudi Arabia, the US, and the UK.
writtenSummary:
The UN says plans by governments to extract fossil fuels up to 2030 are incompatible with keeping global temperatures to safe levels.
A study says coal production will drop but gas will increase over the next 20 years.
The report profiles 15 major production countries including Australia, Russia, Saudi Arabia, the US, and the UK.

title: Jailed Kremlin critic Alexei Navalny wins EU's top human rights award
writtenTitle: Jailed Kremlin critic Alexei Navalny wins EU's top human rights award
summary:
The European Parliament awarded the Sakharov Prize for human rights to jailed Russian opposition figure Navalny, who last year survived a poisoning attack.
His organisation described the award as a victory for all supporters of truth.
The movement headed by the 45-year-old was banned as "extremist" and some of his allies were forced to leave Russia.
writtenSummary:
The European Parliament awarded the Sakharov Prize for human rights to jailed Russian opposition figure Navalny, who last year survived a poisoning attack.
His organisation described the award as a victory for all supporters of truth.

title: Local activists in long battle to stop oil drilling on Isle of Wight
writtenTitle: Local activists in long battle to stop oil drilling on Isle of Wight
summary:
Isle of Wight Council has rejected the UK Oil and Gas Investments proposal to drill for oil on the island.
The oil company had applied to drill two exploratory boreholes near Arreton for recovering 15.7 million barrels of oil.
The decision brought relief to the campaign group - Don't Drill the Wight - which opposed the plans for the past five years.
writtenSummary:
Isle of Wight Council has rejected the UK Oil and Gas Investments proposal to drill for oil on the island.

The decision brought relief to the campaign group - Don't Drill the Wight - which opposed the plans for the past five years.

title: WHO warns pandemic will drag on deep into 2022
writtenTitle: Covid: WHO warns pandemic will drag on deep into 2022
summary:
WHO says the pandemic will go on for a year longer than it needs to as poorer countries are not getting the vaccines they need.
UN-backed global programme Covax aimed to deliver 2 billion doses by the end of this year, but so far it has shipped 371 million doses.
The majority of vaccines were used in high-income or upper-middle-income countries.
writtenSummary:
WHO says the pandemic will go on for a year longer than it needs to as poorer countries are not getting the vaccines they need.
UN-backed global programme Covax aimed to deliver 2 billion doses by the end of this year, but so far it has shipped 371m doses.
The majority of vaccines were used in high-income or upper-middle-income countries.

title: Germany: Health agency forecasts winter spike in Covid cases
writtenTitle: Germany: Health agency forecasts winter spike in COVID cases
summary:
The Robert Koch Institute warned that the country should expect to see another spike in Covid cases for the rest of the fall and winter after months of declining numbers.
It recommended large, un-masked gatherings continue to be avoided at all costs, particularly indoors.
The state leaders want the federal govt to keep restrictions in place.
writtenSummary:
The Robert Koch Institute warned that the country should expect to see another spike in COVID cases for the rest of the fall and winter after months of declining numbers.
It recommended large, un-masked gatherings continue to be avoided at all costs, particularly indoors.
The state leaders want the federal govt to keep restrictions in place.

title: Germany, 4 EU states launch military reaction force initiative
writtenTitle: Germany, 4 EU states launch military reaction force initiative
summary:
Germany, Finland, Netherland, Portugal and Slovenia launched an initiative to establish a bloc-wide rapid reaction force for future military crises.
It aims to expand the EU battle groups, which are multinational military units of 1,500 personnel each.
It may include space and cyber capabilities, along with special forces and air transport.
writtenSummary:
Germany, Finland, Netherland, Portugal, and Slovenia launched an initiative to establish a bloc-wide rapid reaction force for future military crises.
It aims to expand the EU battle groups, which are multinational military units of 1,500 personnel each.
It may include space and cyber capabilities, along with special forces and air transport.

title: Myanmar junta rearrests more than 100 released in amnesty
writtenTitle: Myanmar junta rearrests more than 100 released in amnesty
summary:
A monitoring group said the junta has rearrested at least 110 anti-coup protesters freed in a recent amnesty.
On Monday, the military announced it would free 5,000 people over the Buddhist festival.
But some were rearrested as they reached home while others were taken to the jail entrance, only to be taken back to prison on additional charges.
writtenSummary:
A Monitoring group said the junta has rearrested at least 110 anti-coup protesters freed in a recent amnesty.
On Monday, the military announced it would free 5,000 people over the Buddhist festival.
But some were rearrested as they reached home while others were taken to the jail entrance, only to be taken back to prison on additional charges.

title: Biden says US will defend Taiwan if China attacks
writtenTitle: Biden says US will defend Taiwan if China attacks
summary:
The US has long practised strategic ambiguity when it comes to the issue of defending Taiwan.
It has no official diplomatic ties with Taiwan but sells arms to it as part of its Taiwan Relations Act, which states that the US must help the island defend itself.
Taiwan said it would neither give in to pressure nor rashly advance when it gets support.
writtenSummary:
The US has long practised strategic ambiguity when it comes to the issue of defending Taiwan.
It has no official diplomatic ties with Taiwan but sells arms to it as part of its Taiwan Relations Act, which states that the US must help the island defend itself.
Taiwan said it would neither give in to pressure nor rashly advance when it gets support.

title: Major revelations raise fresh questions for Facebook
writtenTitle: Major revelations raise fresh questions for Facebook
summary:
A group that spread false claims about Covid, more than doubled the average number of interactions it got on Facebook in the first six months of 2021.
Revelations about the World Doctors Alliance pages raise questions about the platform’s efforts to control misinformation.
The figures are revealed in a report by the Institute for Strategic Dialogue.
writtenSummary:
A group that spread false claims about Covid more than doubled the average number of interactions it got on Facebook in the first six months of 2021. 
Revelations about the World Doctors Alliance pages raise questions about the platform’s efforts to control misinformation. 
The figures are revealed in a report by the Institute for Strategic Dialogue.

title: Study: Vikings were in the Americas exactly a thousand years ago
writtenTitle: Study: Vikings were in the Americas exactly a thousand years ago
summary:
The Vikings used their longships to cross the Atlantic Ocean and settled in Canada as early as 1021.
Researchers landed on a definitive date thanks to two sources: chopped wood and a solar storm that occurred more than a thousand years ago.
Securing this date suggests this is the earliest known presence of Europeans in the Americas ahead of Columbus.
writtenSummary:
The Vikings used their longships to cross the Atlantic Ocean and settled in Canada as early as 1021.
Researchers landed on a definitive date thanks to two sources: chopped wood and a solar storm that occurred more than a thousand years ago.
Securing this date suggests this is the earliest known presence of Europeans in the Americas ahead of Columbus.
keywords: thousand years ago Study Vikings Americas thousand years ago Atlantic Ocean Researchers landed definitive date chopped wood solar storm date suggests Americas ahead 1021 Vikings longships cross settled Canada early sources occurred Securing earliest presence Europeans Columbus

title: US records show physical, sexual abuse at border
writtenTitle: US records show physical, sexual abuse at border
summary:
Newly obtained US govt documents by HRW detail over 160 internal reports of abuse of asylum seekers at the hands of US officials.
This raises questions about whether allegations reported internally are being effectively investigated.
HRW urged the US to take steps to ensure that people victimised have access to justice and this misconduct ends.
writtenSummary:
Newly obtained US govt documents by HRW detail over 160 internal reports of abuse of asylum seekers at the hands of US officials.
This raises questions about whether allegations reported internally are being effectively investigated.
HRW urged the US to take steps to ensure that people victimised have access to justice and this misconduct ends.

title: West Africa's Benin votes to legalise abortion
writtenTitle: West Africa's Benin votes to legalise abortion
summary:
Benin authorised abortions after parliamentarians voted on a law that has divided opinion.
Abortion is authorised within the first three months if it aggravates or causes distress, incompatible with the woman or unborn child's interest.
This measure is a relief for many women who are forced to put their lives in danger with botched abortions.
writtenSummary:
Benin authorised abortions after parliamentarians voted on a law that has divided opinion.
Abortion is authorised within the first 3 months if it aggravates or causes distress, incompatible with the woman or unborn child's interest.
This measure is a relief for many women who are forced to put their lives in danger with botched abortions.

title: Syria says it executed 24 people for starting 2020 wildfires
writtenTitle: Syria says it executed 24 people for starting 2020 wildfires
summary:
Syria's government says it has executed 24 people convicted of deliberately starting deadly wildfires last year.
The 2020 wildfires reportedly burned 24,000 hectares of agricultural and forested land.
Human rights groups believe thousands of people have been executed by President Bashar al-Assad's government since the civil war began in 2011.
writtenSummary:
Syria's government says it has executed 24 people convicted of deliberately starting deadly wildfires last year. 
The 2020 wildfires reportedly burned 24,000 hectares of agricultural and forested land. 
Human rights groups believe thousands of people have been executed by President Bashar al-Assad's government since the civil war began in 2011.

title: WHO says Covid may have killed 180,000 health workers
writtenTitle: WHO says COVID may have killed 180,000 health workers
summary:
The WHO has estimated between 80,000 and 180,000 healthcare workers have died worldwide due to Covid.
Healthcare workers have been given priority, but the unequal distribution of jabs means that on average, across the world, only two in five are fully vaccinated.
The WHO has stepped up calls for governments to do more to protect and support workers.
writtenSummary:
The WHO has estimated between 80,000 and 180,000 healthcare workers have died worldwide due to COVID. 
Healthcare workers have been given priority, but the unequal distribution of jabs means that on average, across the world, only two in five are fully vaccinated.
The WHO has stepped up calls for governments to do more to protect and support workers.

title: Haiti gang leader threatens to kill American missionary hostages
writtenTitle: Haiti gang leader threatens to kill American missionary hostages
summary:
The leader of the Haitian gang suspected of kidnapping 17 members of a missionary group from the US has threatened to kill the hostages if his demands are not met.
Earlier this week, Haitian officials said the gang is demanding $1 million in ransom per person to free the hostages.
5 of the abductees are children, including an eight-month-old infant.
writtenSummary:
The leader of the Haitian gang suspected of kidnapping 17 members of a missionary group from the US has threatened to kill the hostages if his demands are not met. 
Earlier this week, Haitian officials said the gang is demanding $1 million in ransom per person to free the hostages.
5 of the abductees are children, including an eight-month-old infant.

title: Twitter admits bias for rightwing politicians and news outlets
writtenTitle: Twitter admits bias for rightwing politicians and news outlets
summary:
Twitter admits to bias in its algorithm after it examined tweets from the UK, US, Canada, France, Germany, Spain & Japan based on research.
The research found tweets from right-wing politicians receiving more amplification than those from the left.
It added that it was preparing to make internal data available to external sources on a regular basis.
writtenSummary:
The research found that tweets from right-wing politicians received more amplification from the algorithm than those from the left.
Twitter has admitted the bias after it examined tweets from the UK, US, Canada, France, Germany, Spain, and Japan.
It added that it was preparing to make internal data available to external sources on a regular basis.

title: US agencies warn climate change poses national security risks
writtenTitle: US agencies warn climate change poses national security risks,
summary:
The US govt has predicted that climate change will exacerbate geopolitical tensions around the world.
The assessments also highlight how global warming will drive mass migration.
11 countries are likely to face warming temperatures, extreme weather, and disruption to ocean patterns that will threaten their energy, food, water, and health security.
writtenSummary:
The US govt has predicted that climate change will exacerbate geopolitical tensions around the world.
 The assessments also highlight how global warming will drive mass migration.
11 countries are likely to face warming temperatures, extreme weather, and disruption to ocean patterns that will threaten their energy, food, water, and health security.

title: Luxembourg becomes first in Europe to legalise growing & using cannabis
writtenTitle: Luxembourg becomes first in Europe to legalise growing, using cannabis
summary:
Adults in Luxembourg will be permitted to grow up to 4 cannabis plants per household for personal use.
Trading seeds will also be permitted without any limit on the quantity or levels of Tetrahydrocannabinol.
The consumption and transport of a quantity of up to 3g will no longer be considered a criminal offence.
writtenSummary:
Adults in Luxembourg will be permitted to grow up to 4 cannabis plants per household for personal use.
Trading seeds will also be permitted without any limit on the quantity or levels of Tetrahydrocannabinol.
The consumption and transport of a quantity of up to 3g will no longer be considered a criminal offence.

title: Violence, roadblocks and armed gangs affect aid relief in Haiti
writtenTitle: Violence, roadblocks, and armed gangs affect Aid relief in Haiti
summary:
The World Food Programme (WFP) is now using seafaring barges to ship supplies to earthquake victims in southern Haiti.
Gang escalating violence has made overland journeys unsafe for aid convoys.
Violence, kidnappings, roadblocks, armed gangs, fuel shortages and reduced supply affect the country and impact relief operations.
writtenSummary:
The World Food Programme (WFP) is now using seafaring barges to ship supplies to earthquake victims in southern Haiti. 
Gang escalating violence has made overland journeys unsafe for aid convoys.
Violence, kidnappings, roadblocks, armed gangs, fuel shortages and reduced supply affect the country and impact relief operations.

title: One of last 2 northern white rhinos dropped from breeding project
writtenTitle: One of last 2 northern white rhinos dropped from breeding project
summary:
Najin, northern white rhinos is being retired from a breeding programme aimed at saving the species from extinction.
Biorescue team cited ethical considerations for the halting of the egg harvesting and said Najin’s age as well as illness, were also taken into account.
Northern white rhinos numbers fell sharply due to poaching for their horns.
writtenSummary:

title: "Stop overfishing or we’ll buy elsewhere," UK top firm warns EU states
writtenTitle: "Stop overfishing or we’ll buy elsewhere," UK top firm warns EU states
summary:
UK’s largest seafood processor is threatening to stop sourcing fish from the northeast Atlantic unless coastal states, including the UK and countries in the EU, reach a suitable agreement.
Fishing quotas for northeast Atlantic fish have exceeded advised levels for more than a decade.
Fishing quotas have been set above the scientifically advised.
writtenSummary:

title: UK Delta 'Plus' Covid variant may be more transmissible
writtenTitle: UK Delta 'Plus' Covid variant may be more transmissible
summary:
A new mutated form of coronavirus that some are calling "Delta Plus" may spread more easily than regular Delta, UK experts say.
The UK Health Security Agency (UKHSA) moved it up into the "variant under investigation" category.
There is no evidence yet that it causes worse illness. Scientists are confident that existing vaccines should still work.
writtenSummary:
A new mutated form of coronavirus that some are calling "Delta Plus" may spread more easily than regular Delta, UK experts say.
The UK Health Security Agency (UKHSA) moved it up into the "variant under investigation" category.
There is no evidence yet that it causes worse illness. Scientists are confident that existing vaccines should still work.

title: Zimbabwe’s older people: the pandemic’s silent victims
writtenTitle: Zimbabwe’s older people: the pandemic’s silent victims
summary:
Care facilities for older people used to be thought ‘un-African’. But destitution caused by Covid has seen demand for care homes soar.
The Zimbabwe National Statistics Agency says 80% of elderly people live in poverty.
Anyone 65 and older is entitled to free healthcare, but hospitals are depleted of supplies.
writtenSummary:
Care facilities for older people used to be thought ‘un-African’. But destitution caused by Covid has seen demand for care homes soar.
The Zimbabwe National Statistics Agency says 80% of elderly people live in poverty.
Anyone 65 and older is entitled to free healthcare, but hospitals are depleted of supplies.

title: China slams Biden’s threat to defend Taiwan in event of war
writtenTitle: China slams Biden’s threat to defend Taiwan in event of war
summary:
China said they would “defend national sovereignty and territorial integrity” and warned the US should not send wrong signals to “separatist forces of Taiwan independence”.
China’s foreign ministry responded there was “no room” for compromise or concessions over Taiwan.
Biden had said the US has a commitment to protect Taiwan in case of an attack
writtenSummary:

writtenTitle: UN fears 'mass atrocity crimes' in Myanmar as troops gather in north
summary:
The UN said it feared a greater human rights catastrophe in Myanmar amid reports of thousands of troops massing in the north of the country.
The findings also indicated that the junta had engaged in probable crimes against humanity and war crimes.
It urged countries to deny the military junta the money, weapons, and legitimacy it desired.

title: EU leaders bid farewell to Merkel at summit
writtenTitle: EU leaders bid farewell to Merkel at summit
summary:
European leaders paid warm tributes to Angela Merkel as they wound up a European Union summit.
Political leaders praise outgoing German chancellor as a ‘compromise machine’ and ‘compass’ of the European project.
Merkel thanked and offered a strong word of caution on the challenges still facing the EU, and her German successor.

title: Young climate activists rally to pressure post-Merkel German govt
writtenTitle: Young climate activists rally to pressure German post-Merkel govt
summary:
Climate activists from the Fridays for Future movement gathered in Berlin demanding an end to empty promises.
They called on the incoming govt to make binding climate protection commitments.
It said the 2030 exit from coal must be legally binding and called for a halt in the production of vehicles using fossil fuels by 2025.
writtenSummary:
Climate activists from the Fridays for Future movement gathered in Berlin demanding an end to empty promises.
They called on the incoming govt to make binding climate protection commitments.
It said the 2030 exit from coal must be legally binding and called for a halt in the production of vehicles using fossil fuels by 2025.

title: Senior al-Qaeda leader killed in US drone strike in Syria
writtenTitle: Senior al-Qaeda leader killed in US drone strike in Syria
summary:
The Pentagon said a senior al-Qaeda leader was killed in a US airstrike in northwest Syria.
It added the removal of this al-Qaida senior leader will disrupt the terrorist organisation's ability to further carry out global attacks threatening US and partners.
The strike comes two days after a US outpost in southern Syria was attacked.
writtenSummary:
The Pentagon said a senior al-Qaeda leader was killed in a US airstrike in northwest Syria.
It added the removal of this al-Qaida senior leader will disrupt the terrorist organisation's ability to further carry out global attacks threatening US and partners.
The strike comes two days after a US outpost in southern Syria was attacked.

title: WTO Director-General calls on Prime Minister Narendra Modi
writtenTitle: WTO Director-General calls on Prime Minister Narendra Modi
summary:
World Trade Organisation Director-General Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala met Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Friday. 
They held discussions on fair and equitable outcomes at the upcoming WTO ministerial conference.
She stressed India’s leadership and wanted the "voice of developing nations" to be heard at the WTO

title: UK: Scientists urge govt to prep rapid return of COVID measures
writtenTitle: UK: Scientists urge govt to prep rapid return of COVID measures
summary:
Scientific advisers urged the govt to ensure covid restrictions can be introduced rapidly, as the rate of new infections increases.
The govt says it may reimpose some restrictions as part of a fall and winter “Plan B” — but not yet.
PM urged people to take precautions such as wearing a mask and getting a booster shot as soon as they were eligible.

title: Trump to launch new social media platform TRUTH Social
writtenTitle: Trump to launch new social media platform TRUTH Social
summary:
Former US President Donald Trump has announced plans to launch a new social media network, called TRUTH Social.
He said the platform would "stand up to the tyranny of big tech", accusing them of silencing opposing voices in the US.
Trump was banned from Twitter and suspended from Facebook after his supporters stormed the US Capitol.

Trump was banned from Twitter and suspended from Facebook after his supporters stormed the US Capitol.

title: New space race? US tests components for hypersonic weapons
writtenTitle: US tests components for hypersonic weapons
summary:
US forces have conducted three tests of hypersonic missile component prototypes, amid concerns from Biden about China’s advances in hypersonic weapons.
The US army and navy are set to conduct hypersonic missile test flights in 2022.
These weapons travel in the upper atmosphere at more than five times the speed of sound and can evade radar systems.

title: Nasa announces uncrewed flights around the Moon to begin in Feb 2022
writtenTitle: Nasa announces uncrewed flights around the Moon to begin in Feb 2022
summary:
The US space agency said that it was in the final phase of testing to send its Orion capsule on an orbit around the Moon on its Space Launch System rocket.
The launch will pave way for the resumption of people to walk on Earth’s satellite again.
It announced this week that Orion was secured to the 98m rocket.

title: Actor Alec Baldwin was given loaded weapon and told it was safe
writtenTitle: Actor Alec Baldwin was given loaded weapon and told it was safe
summary:
Baldwin was handed a loaded weapon by an assistant director who indicated it was safe to use in the moments before the actor fatally shot a cinematographer Hutchins.
The assistant director did not know the prop gun was loaded with live rounds.
Experts say guns used in making movies are sometimes real weapons that can fire either bullets or blanks.
writtenSummary:
Baldwin was handed a loaded weapon by an assistant director who indicated it was safe to use in the moments before the actor fatally shot a cinematographer Hutchins.

title: Budget 2021: Ministers pledge £500m to support young families
writtenTitle: Budget 2021: Ministers pledge £500m to support young families
summary:
Ministers are to fund a network of "family hubs" in England as part of a £500m package to support parents and children.
The centres in 75 different areas will provide a "one-stop-shop" for support and advice.
The funding, to be announced by the chancellor in Wednesday's Budget, will also go towards breastfeeding advice and mental health services.

title: Twitter says Online Safety Bill needs more clarity
writtenTitle: Twitter says Online Safety Bill needs more clarity
summary:
Government plans for social media regulation need "far more clarity", said a Twitter boss.
Katy Minshall said the draft Online Safety Bill fails to answer key concerns and risks leaving the regulator Ofcom to "muddle through".
She also said plans to fine rule-breaking companies posed an "almost existential" threat.

title: Orion: Nasa's Moon-ship is attached to SLS megarocket
writtenTitle: Orion: Nasa's Moon-ship is attached to SLS megarocket
summary:
Nasa's next-generation spaceship has been lifted onto the rocket that will launch it to the Moon this year or in early 2022.
On Wednesday, the Orion spacecraft was attached to the powerful Space Launch System (SLS) rocket at Nasa's Kennedy Space Center in Florida.
For its upcoming flight, Orion will fly around the Moon without astronauts.

title: US Supreme Court will take up case on Texas abortion law
writtenTitle: US Supreme Court will take up case on Texas abortion law
summary:
Even though US Supreme Court will allow Texas to maintain a near-total ban on abortions, it will take up the case next month in a sped-up process.
The law gives persons the right to sue doctors who perform an abortion past 6 weeks before women know of the pregnancy.
The Court will focus on how the law was crafted and if it can be legally challenged.

title: Covid boosters: US approves Moderna and J&J shots
writtenTitle: Covid boosters: US approves Moderna and J&J shots
summary:
US approved Moderna and Johnson & Johnson vaccines to be used as booster jabs.
This comes a month after the FDA authorised Pfizer booster jabs for some Americans, including those over 65 or at higher risk of severe illness and who work in frontline jobs.
Less than 5% of Americans have so far received a booster jab.

title: Barbados elects first-ever president ahead of becoming republic
writtenTitle: Barbados elects first-ever president ahead of becoming republic
summary:
The Caribbean island has elected its first-ever president as it prepares to become a republic, removing Queen Elizabeth as head of state.
72-year-old Dame Sandra Mason, set to be sworn in on November 30, has been Barbados' governor-general since 2018.
Barbados will not be the first former British colony in the Caribbean to become a republic.

The Caribbean island has elected its first-ever president as it prepares to become a republic, removing Queen Elizabeth as head of state.

Barbados will not be the first former British colony in the Caribbean to become a republic.

title: Haiti sees nearly 800 kidnappings so far this year, NGO says
writtenTitle: Haiti sees nearly 800 kidnappings so far this year, NGO says
summary:
Nearly 800 kidnappings have been reported in Haiti so far this year, as gangs expand their control amid political instability.
"Citizens do not trust the Haitian national police", Gedeon Jean, the CARDH director, said.
"Some policemen are active in gangs and others provide cover, allowing gangs to operate, or they share information with them".
writtenSummary:
Nearly 800 kidnappings have been reported in Haiti so far this year, as gangs expand their control amid political instability. 
"Citizens do not trust the Haitian national police", Gedeon Jean, the CARDH director, said. 
"Some policemen are active in gangs and others provide cover, allowing gangs to operate, or they share information with them".

title: Outcry as Israel labels Palestinian rights groups "terrorists"
writtenTitle: Outcry as Israel labels Palestinian rights groups "terrorists"
summary:
The designation effectively outlaws the activities of the groups, subjecting their members to raids and arrests.
Israel said the groups were linked to the PFLP, a left-wing faction with an armed wing that has carried out attacks against Israelis.
This decision is an attack by Israel on the international human rights movement, Amnesty and HRW said.

title: 52% of women were 7 months into menopause before realizing what it was
writtenTitle: 52% of women were 7 months into menopause before realizing what it was
summary:
Over half of women didn’t realize they were going through menopause until 7 months after they first experienced signs, a poll found.
30% wish there had been more education available about what to expect during menopause.
Nearly two-thirds agreed menopause shouldn’t be a taboo topic and over half admitted it is so much more than when your period ends.

writtenTitle: Istanbul improves lives of stray cats with elaborate cat houses
summary:
Estimated at 125,000, the stray cat population of Istanbul is a more appreciated component of the metropolis.
Volunteers build houses where cats can find food and toys, cushions and boxes to keep them out of harsh weather, and even a new owner.
This allows volunteers, who often organize via WhatsApp groups, to keep a closer eye on the cats’ lives.

The claims echo those of the whistleblower Haugen, a former FB employee who said the company prioritises profit over public safety. 
The whistleblower claims came on the same day that news outlets published reports shared by Haugen.

writtenTitle: Israel labels Palestinian rights groups as terrorist organisations
summary:
Israel has accused Al-Haq, Addameer, Defence for Children International, Bisan Center for Research and Development, the Union of Palestinian Women’s Committees, and Union of Agricultural Work Committees as terrorist organisations.

title: Ethiopian govt airstrike on Tigray forced UN to abort flight in midair
writtenTitle: Ethiopian govt airstrike on Tigray forced UN to abort flight in midair
summary:
The UN has suspended its twice-weekly passenger flights to Mekelle for humanitarian personnel after the plane had to abort the landing.
The passengers were aid workers traveling to a region where 7 million people, including 5 million in Tigray, need humanitarian help.
UN says govt was aware of the plane carrying the aid workers.

title: Otoniel: Colombia’s most-wanted drug lord captured
writtenTitle: Otoniel: Colombia’s most-wanted drug lord captured
summary:
Dairo Antonio Usuga, alias "Otoniel", top leader of the Gulf Clan, was arrested on Saturday during an operation in a rural area of Colombia’s Uraba region.
President Ivan Duque said Otoniel’s arrest is the biggest blow to drug trafficking in the country since Pablo Escobar’s death.
One police officer died during the operation, the president said.
writtenSummary:
Dairo Antonio Usuga, alias "Otoniel", top leader of the Gulf Clan, was arrested on Saturday during an operation in a rural area of Colombia’s Uraba region. 
President Ivan Duque said Otoniel’s arrest is the biggest blow to drug trafficking in the country since Pablo Escobar’s death. 
One police officer died during the operation, the president said.

title: Muqtada al-Sadr: Iraq’s kingmaker in uncertain times
writtenTitle: Muqtada al-Sadr: Iraq’s kingmaker in uncertain times
summary:
Muqtada al-Sadr is currently considered the kingmaker, but it remains unclear if he can form a gov't with stability.
Al-Sadr’s party controls 70 of a total of 329 parliamentary seats in Iraq and the movement has a large base across the country.
Any coalition al-Sadr may or may not be able to form is likely to have an adverse effect on his own party.

writtenTitle: Afghan National Music Institute strikes a chord in Qatar
summary:

The school’s mantra includes ensuring the musical rights of all Afghans and promoting gender-equal learning.

title: Sam Altman wants to scan your eyes in exchange for free cryptocurrency
writtenTitle: Sam Altman wants to scan your eyes in exchange for free cryptocurrency
summary:
Tech millionaire Altman's new start-up Worldcoin uses orb-shaped devices to scan people's eyes in exchange for free cryptocurrency.
The image is encrypted and becomes a unique code, while the original data is deleted to protect users' privacy.
The company has so far amassed over 100,000 users globally already and aims to hit 1 billion users by 2023.
writtenSummary:

title: Maybe the metaverse can save Facebook. Maybe.
writtenTitle: Maybe the metaverse can save Facebook. Maybe.
summary:
Facebook is trying to emphasise its new name and its push into the metaverse.
It's a "genius" move in the world of branding strategy that could help Facebook, experts said, but ultimately it may not be enough to save the company's reputation.
At the epicentre of Facebook's recent PR woes is a series of leaked documents given to the WSJ by Haugen.

writtenTitle: Report: Facebook whistleblower says site enables illegal drug trades
summary:
A new whistleblower has filed an SEC complaint against the company, according to documents obtained by the Post.
The invite-only communities were poorly monitored by Facebook, enabling terrifying and aberrant behaviours, the whistleblower said.
The whistleblower was reportedly told to "focus on the good" by Facebook officials after raising concerns.

title: Facebook boss "not willing to protect public from harm"
writtenTitle: Facebook boss ‘not willing to protect public from harm’
summary:
Frances Haugen has launched a new criticism of Zuckerberg, saying he has not shown any readiness to protect the public from the harm his company is causing.
He has not displayed a desire to run the company in a way that shields the public from the consequences of harmful content.
“Right now, Mark is unaccountable. He has all the control,” she said

title: UK: Pub to hold girls-only night each week, fears of injection spiking
writtenTitle: Pub holding girls-only night each week amid fears of injection spiking
summary:
Nottingham pub is set to introduce a weekly girls-only night following reports of spiking in the city.
The Playwright will hold its first girls-only event on 3 November.
It comes after two men were arrested on suspicion of conspiring to administer poison in connection with a spate of reported drink-spiking incidents involving needles in Nottingham.

title: More than a million people may now have Covid in England
writtenTitle: More than a million people may now have Covid in England
summary:
There are now 977,900 people in England with Covid-19, equating to around one in 55 people.
At the peak of the second wave, one in 50 was thought to have Covid, and it’s feared the real figure could be higher than the estimate.
The Office for National Statistics said children in school years 7 to 11 had the highest percentage of positive tests.

A footage, which has been uploaded on social medial, reveals that the incident occurred on Oct 18.
Police launched investigation after seeing the video.

title: ‘I hug them’: meet the American farmer raising 2,000lb pumpkins
writtenTitle: ‘I hug them’: meet the American farmer raising 2,000lb pumpkins
summary:
Leonardo Urena is part of an elite group of global growers with golden seeds – and this year produced California’s largest specimen of the the world’s biggest pumpkin.
With cultivation and care, he brings several of these orange giants to life each year.
Urena also grows a wide variety of fruits, vegetables and flowers, from mini gourds to beets.

title: Social care crisis: Woman, 92, waited 4 months to be discharged
writtenTitle: Social care crisis: Woman, 92, waited four months to be discharged
summary:
There were over 1,000 patients in Welsh hospitals unable to return home due to a lack of care, according to Welsh Government figures last month.
All Care said staffing levels were at their lowest since 2002.
Director Keri said care staff were exhausted from working through the pandemic, while low wages made recruitment and staff retention difficult.
writtenSummary:
There were over 1,000 patients in Welsh hospitals unable to return home due to a lack of care, according to Welsh Government figures last month. 
All Care said staffing levels were at their lowest since 2002.
Director Keri said care staff were exhausted from working through the pandemic, while low wages made recruitment and staff retention difficult.

title: Fan's Lego City Ground to feature in Nottingham Forest programme
writtenTitle: Fan's Lego City Ground to feature in Nottingham Forest programme
summary:
A football fan who built a Lego model of his club's stadium has said he is "extremely excited" that it will feature in a match-day programme.
36-year-old Jonny Heald said he first tried to recreate the stadium as an eight-year-old in 1994, after seeing his first Nottingham Forest home game.
He hopes it could be displayed at the ground.

A football fan who built a Lego model of his club's stadium has said he is "extremely excited" that it will feature in a match-day programme.

He now hopes it could be displayed at the ground.

title: England beat West Indies, 55, by 6 wickets
writtenTitle: England beat West Indies, 55, by 6 wickets
summary:
England’s introduction to the T20 World Cup fell not far short of perfection as they skittled the defending champions West Indies.
Their performance in the field had been so good the occasional stumble in the chase hardly mattered.
West Indies’ feared batting lineup having been remorselessly shredded.

title: Travellers now able to use cheaper Covid tests
writtenTitle: Covid: Travellers now able to use cheaper Covid tests
summary:
New rules allowing travellers returning to England to take lateral flow tests instead of more expensive PCR tests have come into force.
The lateral flow tests for returning travellers must be bought from private providers - NHS kits cannot be used.
Anyone who tested positive would have to take a PCR test, which they could get free through the NHS.
writtenSummary:

The lateral flow tests for returning travellers must be bought from private providers - NHS kits cannot be used. 
Anyone who tested positive would have to take a PCR test, which they could get free through the NHS.

title: Tesco website hit by hackers, leaving thousands of shoppers frustrated
writtenTitle: Tesco website hit by hackers, leaving thousands of shoppers frustrated
summary:
Tesco has been hit by hackers, leaving thousands of frustrated shoppers unable to buy groceries online at Britain’s biggest supermarket.
Tesco receives 1.3 mn online orders every week.
The company's spokesperson said an attempt was made to interfere with their systems, which has caused problems with the search function on the site.
writtenSummary:
Tesco has been hit by hackers, leaving thousands of frustrated shoppers unable to buy groceries online at Britain’s biggest supermarket.
Tesco receives 1.3 M online orders every week.
There is no reason to believe that this issue impacts customer data and we continue to take ongoing action to make sure all data stays safe, a Tesco spokesperson said.

title: NASA will send its uncrewed Artemis mission to the moon in Feb 2022
writtenTitle: NASA will send its uncrewed Artemis mission to the moon in Feb 2022
summary:
The uncrewed Artemis I mission will launch in February 2022.
NASA recently completed the stacking of its Orion spacecraft on the Space Launch System, the world’s most powerful rocket.
The idea is to test out rockets and systems ahead of a crewed mission to orbit the moon, known as Artemis II, followed by Artemis III - a crewed landing on the moon.
writtenSummary:
The uncrewed Artemis I mission will launch in February 2022. 
NASA recently completed the stacking of its Orion spacecraft on the Space Launch System, the world’s most powerful rocket. 
The idea is to test out rockets and systems ahead of a crewed mission to orbit the moon, known as Artemis II, followed by Artemis III - a crewed landing on the moon.

title: Turkey’s Erdogan orders expulsion of 10 Western ambassadors
writtenTitle: Turkey’s Erdogan orders expulsion of 10 Western ambassadors
summary:
President Erdogan moved to expel the ambassadors of 10 Western countries who appealed for the release of a jailed civil society leader.
Seven of the ambassadors represent Turkey’s NATO allies - the USA and France.
Osman Kavala has been in prison since late 2017, charged with financing nationwide protests and involvement in a 2016 failed coup.
writtenSummary:
President Erdogan moved to expel the ambassadors of 10 Western countries who appealed for the release of a jailed civil society leader
Seven of the ambassadors represent Turkey’s NATO allies, e.g. the USA and France
Osman Kavala has been in prison since late 2017, charged with financing nationwide protests and with involvement in a 2016 failed coup

title: Social justice ministry suggests humane approach for drug users
writtenTitle: Social justice ministry recommends more humane approach for drug users
summary:
The ministry has recommended changes to the NDPS Act to exempt drug users and addicts from a prison term.
It has suggested that drug users and addicts be treated as "victims" who are in need of de-addiction and rehabilitation.
The ministry has also called for decriminalising possession of "small quantities" of drugs for personal consumption.
writtenSummary:
The ministry has recommended changes to the NDPS Act to exempt drug users and addicts from a prison term. 
It has suggested that drug users and addicts be treated as "victims" who are in need of de-addiction and rehabilitation. 
The ministry has also called for decriminalising possession of "small quantities" of drugs for personal consumption.

title: Spanish scientists help blind woman to see forms with brain implant
writtenTitle: Spanish scientists help blind woman to see forms with brain implant
summary:
The groundbreaking project enabled former biology teacher Bernardeta Gómez to recognise shapes and letters, and even play a simplified version of the Pac-Man computer game.
The system consists of a 96-electrode implant that is placed in the rear brain region responsible for vision.
Gómez's blindness returned once she was unhooked from the system.
writtenSummary:
The groundbreaking project enabled former biology teacher Bernardeta Gómez to recognize shapes and letters, and even play a simplified version of the Pac-Man computer game. 
The system consists of a 96-electrode implant that is placed in the rear brain region responsible for vision. 
Gómez's blindness returned once she was unhooked from the system.

title: US: Rust assistant director was subject of 2019 safety complaint
writtenTitle: US: Rust assistant director was subject of 2019 safety complaint
summary:
A crew member disclosed that she had raised safety concerns in the past about the assistant director who unwittingly handed actor Baldwin the prop gun that killed a cinematographer on a film set.
She said, “It’s in no way one person’s fault, it’s a bigger conversation about safety on set.”
Half a dozen crew members protested against safety concerns.
writtenSummary:
A crew member disclosed that she had raised safety concerns in the past about the assistant director who unwittingly handed actor Baldwin the prop gun that killed a cinematographer on a film set.
She said, “It’s in no way one person’s fault, it’s a bigger conversation about safety on set.”
Half a dozen crew members protested against safety concerns.

title: Sudan: Civilian leaders arrested amid reports of a coup
writtenTitle: Sudan: Civilian leaders arrested amid reports of a coup
summary:
Unidentified gunmen arrested several Sudanese leaders, after weeks of tension between the military and civilian transitional authorities.
The internet was cut off throughout the country, while demonstrators protested against the arrests.
Analysts say recent mass demonstrations show strong support for a civilian-led democracy.
writtenSummary:
Unidentified gunmen arrested several Sudanese leaders, after weeks of tension between the military and civilian transitional authorities.
The internet was cut off throughout the country, while demonstrators protested against the arrests.
Analysts say recent mass demonstrations show strong support for a civilian-led democracy.

title: China postpones Beijing marathon due to Covid surge
writtenTitle: China postpones Beijing marathon due to Covid surge
summary:
The Beijing Marathon is postponed until further notice, as its health official warned that a fresh outbreak of cases is expected to spread further.
China has reported more than 133 cases across 11 provinces, all linked to the Delta variant.
The latest surge is considered the largest outbreak in the country since Nanjing in August this year.
writtenSummary:
The Beijing Marathon is postponed until further notice, as its health official warned that a fresh outbreak of cases is expected to spread further.
China has reported more than 133 cases across 11 provinces so far, all linked to the Delta variant.
The latest surge is considered the largest outbreak in the country since Nanjing in August this year.

title: Why some PCR results were negative after a positive lateral flow test
writtenTitle: Why some PCR results were negative after a positive lateral flow test
summary:
The UKHSA began an investigation after seeing a rapid rise in negative results from PCR tests following positive lateral flow tests among schoolchildren.
In the end, the phenomenon was traced back to the Immensa Health Clinic, which the UKHSA described as an isolated incident attributed to one lab.
All samples are now being redirected to other labs.
writtenSummary:
The UKHSA began an investigation after seeing a rapid rise in negative results from PCR tests following positive lateral flow tests among schoolchildren. 
In the end, the phenomenon was traced back to the Immensa Health Clinic, which the UKHSA described as an isolated incident attributed to one lab.
All samples are now being redirected to other labs.

title: Father of Molly Russell meets Facebook whistleblower Frances Haugen
writtenTitle: Father of Molly Russell meets Facebook whistleblower Frances Haugen
summary:
FB whistleblower Haugen met the campaigner Ian Russell, whose 14-year-old daughter died by suicide after viewing disturbing content on Instagram. 
Haugen will give evidence to MPs as part of govt plans for social media regulation.
She leaked documents that she said proved the company’s repeatedly prioritised growth over users' safety.
writtenSummary:
FB whistleblower Haugen met the campaigner Ian Russell, whose 14-year-old daughter died by suicide after viewing disturbing content on Instagram owned by FB. 
Haugen will give evidence to MPs as part of govt plans for social media regulation.
She leaked documents that she said proved the company’s repeatedly prioritised growth over users' safety.

title: "Most influential" climate science paper of all time won a Nobel Prize
writtenTitle: "Most influential" climate science paper of all time won a Nobel Prize
summary:
After WWII, many of Japan’s scientists found jobs in North American labs, including Manabe.
Working alongside Joseph, the Geophysical Fluid Dynamics Laboratory‘s director, Manabe led a team to add missing physics to the lab’s weather model.
The climate model development was an ambitious 20-year project that ultimately earned Manabe the Nobel Prize.

After WWII, many of Japan’s scientists found jobs in North American labs, including Manabe. 
Working alongside Joseph, the Geophysical Fluid Dynamics Laboratory‘s director, Manabe led a team to add missing physics to the lab’s weather model. 
The climate model development was an ambitious 20-year project that ultimately earned Manabe the Nobel Prize.

title: Study: Standing is associated with better insulin sensitivity
writtenTitle: Study: Standing is associated with better insulin sensitivity
summary:
Lifestyle has a strong impact on insulin resistance and the development of type 2 diabetes.
Researchers observed standing is associated with better insulin sensitivity independently of the amount of daily physical activity or sitting time, fitness level, or overweight.
Increasing the daily standing time may therefore help prevent chronic diseases.

Researchers observed standing is associated with better insulin sensitivity independently of the amount of daily physical activity or sitting time, fitness level, or overweight. 
Increasing the daily standing time may therefore help prevent chronic diseases.

title: Squid Game helps Netflix subscriptions pick up
summary:
Netflix subscriptions picked up in the 3rd quarter of 2021 as non-English language shows continued to be the streaming platform's best performers.
Netflix added 4.4 million users in the three months to 30 September, over double in the previous quarter.
Korean TV series Squid Game was its biggest hit, watched by 142 million households in its first 4 weeks. But, why are some health professionals warning that the show is “clearly not appropriate for children”?

title: Senegalese women wage war against climate injustice
writtenTitle: Senegalese women wage war against climate injustice
summary:
Senegalese women took to the streets of Dakar to march against climate change.
Their objective was to promote women's participation in the climate debate and encourage people to consider their climate concerns at the Glasgow climate summit.
The year 2020 reached temperatures about 1.02°C warmer than average, which was felt intensely across Africa.

Senegalese women took to the streets of Dakar to march against climate change.
Their objective was to promote women's participation in the climate debate and encourage people to consider their climate concerns at the Glasgow climate summit.

title: Ethiopia: The ongoing humanitarian crisis in Tigray
writtenTitle: Ethiopia: The ongoing humanitarian crisis in Tigray
summary:
As attacks against the Tigrayan People’s Liberation Front are increasing, the humanitarian situation continues to deteriorate.
It has been described as the world’s worst hunger crisis in a decade and it is feared the situation will become even bleaker.
The UN has suspended all humanitarian flights to the regional capital, Mekelle.
writtenSummary:
As attacks against the Tigrayan People’s Liberation Front are increasing, the humanitarian situation continues to deteriorate.
It has been described as the world’s worst hunger crisis in a decade and it is feared the situation will become even bleaker.
The UN has suspended all humanitarian flights to the regional capital, Mekelle.

title: Germany: Far-right vigilante border patrols stopped near Polish border
writtenTitle: Germany: Far-right vigilante border patrols stopped near Polish border
summary:
German police stopped dozens of armed, far-right vigilantes patrolling to stop migrants from entering Germany via the Polish border. 
The group had answered a call by the German far-right party The Third Way (Der Dritte Weg), which had urged members to stop migrants.
The largest group of about 30 people, was encountered near Gross Gastrose.
writtenSummary:

The largest group of about 30 people, was encountered near Gross Gastrose.

title: Vaccination is not a silver bullet, WHO chief scientist says
writtenTitle: 'Vaccination is not a silver bullet,' WHO chief scientist says
summary:
Dr Soumya Swaminathan says rich nations must stop being greedy with vaccines if they want to end the pandemic.
She called for expanded vaccine equity and sharing of tools in poorer countries.
She said "Vaccines are very effective against protecting against severe disease. But vaccines are not 100% effective against infection."
writtenSummary:
Dr. Soumya Swaminathan says rich nations must stop being greedy with vaccines if they want to end the pandemic.
She called for expanded vaccine equity and sharing of tools in poorer countries.
She said "Vaccines are very effective against protecting against severe disease...But vaccines are not 100% effective against infection."

title: Sudan PM moved to unknown location after refusing to support coup
writtenTitle: Sudan PM moved to unknown location after refusing to support coup
summary:
Hamdok was moved to an unknown location after refusing to issue a statement in support of an ongoing military coup, the information ministry said.
It cited Hamdok calling on the Sudanese people to resist the coup attempt peacefully.
The coup happened in spite of an agreement Hamdok had reached with al-Burhan, the head of the country’s ruling council.

The coup happened in spite of an agreement Hamdok had reached with al-Burhan, the head of the country’s ruling council.

title: Amnesty International to close Hong Kong offices
writtenTitle: Amnesty International to close Hong Kong offices
summary:
Amnesty will close its HK offices by the end of the year, citing concerns for the safety of staff trying to operate under the national security law.
Last month it said authorities were exercising “virtually unchecked investigative powers”.
It conducted research and advocacy related to the 2019 mass protests and subsequent crackdown by authorities.
writtenSummary:
Amnesty will close its HK offices by the end of the year, citing concerns for the safety of staff trying to operate under the national security law.
Last month it said authorities were exercising “virtually unchecked investigative powers”.
It conducted research and advocacy related to the 2019 mass protests and subsequent crackdown by authorities.

writtenTitle: T20 World Cup: Afghan cricket team hopes to put "smiles on faces"
summary:
Afghanistan cricket team will take the field on Monday in the T20 World Cup, its first outing since the Taliban takeover of the nation.
Sport in Afghanistan faced an uncertain future following the Taliban’s takeover of the country in August.
Afghanistan Cricket Board’s recently appointed Chairman Fazli said there is no ban on women’s sport as of yet.

title: Turkish lira drops to record low on President Erdogan's comments
writtenTitle: Turkish lira drops to record low on President Erdogan comments
summary:
Turkey's lira fell to a fresh record low after Erdogan said he had ordered the expulsion of the envoys of 10 Western countries.
Erdogan said he had told his foreign ministry to expel the envoys for demanding the release of Kavala.
Erdogan's political opponents said his call to expel envoys was an attempt to distract from the country's economic woes.

title: Next-generation batteries could use material derived from trees
writtenTitle: Next-generation batteries could use material derived from trees
summary:
Scientists have developed a tree-derived material to be used in solid-state batteries, which are safer and less environmentally damaging than current batteries.
The material is thin and flexible, which makes it easier to use in manufacturing.
Using materials nature provides will reduce the overall impact of battery manufacture on our environment.
writtenSummary:
Scientists have developed a tree-derived material to be used in solid-state batteries, which are safer and less environmentally damaging than current batteries. 
The material is thin and flexible, which makes it easier to use in manufacturing. 
Using materials nature provides will reduce the overall impact of battery manufacture on our environment.

title: Crunchy algae, anyone? NASA shares ideas for food in space
writtenTitle: Crunchy algae, anyone? NASA shares ideas for food in space
summary:
NASA recently held a challenge asking organisations and members of the public to submit their most daring concepts of how to feed astronauts.
The winning entries included growing microalgae and dehydrating them into “crunchy bite-sized snacks”.
The development of unusual food products and food systems could also benefit all of us here on Earth.
writtenSummary:
NASA recently held a challenge asking organizations and members of the public to submit their most daring concepts of how to feed astronauts. 
The winning entries included growing microalgae and dehydrating them into “crunchy bite-sized snacks”. 
The development of unusual food products and food systems could also benefit all of us here on Earth.

title: National Living Wage set to rise to £9.50 an hour
writtenTitle: National Living Wage set to rise to £9.50 an hour
summary:
The National Living Wage is set to rise from £8.91 per hour to £9.50 in the Budget.
This is a 6.6% increase in the minimum wage for all those aged 23 and over - more than twice the current 3.1% rise in the cost of living.
The government has come under pressure to help low-paid employees and younger workers, who are among the worst hit by Covid.
writtenSummary:
The National Living Wage is set to rise from £8.91 per hour to £9.50 in the Budget.
This is a 6.6% increase in the minimum wage for all those aged 23 and over - more than twice the current 3.1% rise in the cost of living.
The government has come under pressure to help low-paid employees and younger workers, who are among the worst hit by Covid.

title: UK: Recycling plastics does not work, says Boris Johnson
writtenTitle: Recycling plastics does not work, says Boris Johnson
summary:
Recycling plastic materials "doesn't work" and "is not the answer" to threats to global oceans and marine wildlife, PM Boris Johnson said.
Answering children's questions ahead of the COP26 climate change summit, the PM said reusing plastics "doesn't begin to address the problem".
Instead, he said, "we've all got to cut down our use of plastic".
writtenSummary:
Recycling plastic materials "doesn't work" and "is not the answer" to threats to global oceans and marine wildlife, Boris Johnson has said.
Answering children's questions ahead of the COP26 climate change summit, the PM said reusing plastics "doesn't begin to address the problem".
Instead, he said, "we've all got to cut down our use of plastic".

title: German jailed in one of first trials for war crimes against Yazidis
writtenTitle: German jailed in one of first trials for war crimes against Yazidis
summary:
A German woman and former member of the self-proclaimed Islamic State group was given a 10-year prison sentence by a Munich court.
She was sentenced for letting a Yazidi girl enslaved in Iraq die of thirst.
The landmark case was one of the first trials in the world to prosecute a war crime against the Yazidis.
writtenSummary:
A German woman and former member of the self-proclaimed Islamic State group was given a 10-year prison sentence by a Munich court.
she was sentenced for letting a Yazidi girl enslaved in Iraq die of thirst.
The landmark case was one of the first trials in the world to prosecute a war crime against the Yazidis.

title: Paris is investing €250 million to become a 100% "cycling city"
writtenTitle: Paris is investing €250 million to become a 100% ‘cycling city’
summary:
Paris aims to become one of the most bike-friendly cities in Europe by 2026.
It is investing €250 million into significant upgrades to cycling infrastructure and maintenance within the next four years.
Thousands of new bicycle stands and an increased number of protected cycleways will be introduced as part of ‘Plan Velo: Act 2’.
writtenSummary:
Paris aims to become one of the most bike-friendly cities in Europe by 2026.
It is investing €250 million into significant upgrades to cycling infrastructure and maintenance within the next four years.
Thousands of new bicycle stands and an increased number of protected cycleways will be introduced as part of ‘Plan Velo: Act 2’.

title: £2bn for new homes on derelict or unused land
writtenTitle: Budget 2021: £2bn for new homes on derelict or unused land
summary:
Almost £2bn will be invested by the government into building new homes on derelict or unused land in England, the chancellor is expected to announce in the Budget.
UK government said 160,000 greener homes could be built on brownfield land the size of 2,000 football pitches.
It also pledged to invest £9m towards 100 urban "pocket parks" across the UK.
writtenSummary:
Almost £2bn will be invested by the government into building new homes on derelict or unused land in England, the chancellor is expected to announce in the Budget.
UK government said 160,000 greener homes could be built on brownfield land the size of 2,000 football pitches.
It also pledged to invest £9m towards 100 urban "pocket parks" across the UK.

title: China president Xi Jinping marks 50th anniversary at UN
writtenTitle: China president Xi Jinping marks 50th anniversary at UN
summary:
China's Xi Jinping marked the country's 50 years of membership in the UN with a speech calling for greater global cooperation.
China was a founding member of the UN but was blocked by the US from taking up its seat until 1971.
In 2018 China was one of the largest financial contributors to the UN, its contribution rose to 12% of the UN budget in 2019.
writtenSummary:
China's Xi Jinping marked the country's 50 years of membership in the UN with a speech calling for greater global cooperation.
China was a founding member of the UN but was blocked by the US from taking up its seat until 1971.
He repeated discussed issues such as terrorism, climate change and cyber security required multilateral solutions.

title: Child dies after migrant boat rescue off the Canary Islands
writtenTitle: Child dies after migrant boat rescue off the Canary Islands
summary:
Emergency agencies in Spain’s Canary Islands have said a child was found dead following a rescue operation from a migrant boat drifting in the Atlantic Ocean.
Two adults and six children found on the boat some 185 km southwest of Gran Canaria were evacuated for urgent medical care.
The people rescued suffered from hypothermia and dehydration.
writtenSummary:
Emergency agencies in Spain’s Canary Islands have said a child was found dead following a rescue operation from a migrant boat drifting in the Atlantic Ocean.
Two adults and six children found on the boat some 185 km southwest of Gran Canaria were evacuated for urgent medical care.
The people rescued suffered from hypothermia and dehydration.

title: Budget 2021: NHS in England to receive £5.9bn to cut waiting lists
writtenTitle: Budget 2021: NHS in England to receive £5.9bn to cut waiting lists
summary:
The NHS in England is to receive an extra £5.9bn in this week's Budget, the UK government has announced.
The money will be used to help clear the record backlog of people waiting for tests and scans, which has been worsened by the pandemic, and also to buy equipment and improve IT.
Chancellor Rishi Sunak called the announcement "game-changing".
writtenSummary:
The NHS in England is to receive an extra £5.9bn in this week's Budget, the UK government has announced.
The money will be used to help clear the record backlog of people waiting for tests and scans, which has been worsened by the pandemic, and also to buy equipment and improve IT.
Chancellor Rishi Sunak called the announcement "game-changing".

title: India: Migrant workers are integral part of Kashmir’s economy
writtenTitle: India: Migrant workers are integral part of Kashmir’s economy
summary:
Migrant labourers have become an integral part of Kashmir’s economy, who are spread across sectors such as agriculture, manufacturing, construction, barbers and hawkers.
In the past two weeks, 11 civilians, including migrant labour and non-Muslim Kashmiris, have been killed.
There is a fear that migrant labourers will not return to Kashmir next year.

title: Recycling plastics does not work, says PM Boris Johnson
writtenTitle: Recycling plastics does not work, says Boris Johnson
summary:
Recycling plastic materials "doesn't work" and "is not the answer" to threats to global oceans and marine wildlife, PM Boris Johnson believes.
He said, "we've all got to cut down our use of plastic".
The Recycling Association's Simon Ellin said Johnson's comments were "very disappointing" and seemed to conflict with government policy.

Instead, he said, "we've all got to cut down our use of plastic".
The Recycling Association's Simon Ellin said Mr Johnson's comments were "very disappointing" and seemed to conflict with government policy.

title: Dutch psychologist says he sold "suicide powder" to over 100 people
writtenTitle: Dutch psychologist says he sold ‘suicide powder’ to over 100 people
summary:
The Netherlands has laws that make it difficult for people to end their lives.
Wim van Dijk gave people "suicide powder" to provoke debate about the laws. Van Dijk works with the Coöperatie Laatste Wil, or the Last Will Cooperative, which campaigns for more liberal legislation.
He said he was unconcerned that he could be jailed over his actions.

title: Sudan Prime Minister detained, state of emergency declared
writtenTitle: Military coup in Sudan -Prime Minister detained: Live Updates
summary:
Sudan's PM has been arrested in a military takeover and taken to an undisclosed location, a senior adviser said.
A military officer dissolved Sudan's ruling council and transitional government and declared a state of emergency.
The US rejected the actions by the military and called for the immediate release of the prime minister and others detained.
writtenSummary:

A military officer dissolved Sudan's ruling council and transitional government and declared a state of emergency.
The US rejected the actions by the military and called for the immediate release of the prime minister and others detained.

title: Facebook whistleblower warns of riots and genocides if no action taken
writtenTitle: Facebook whistleblower warns of riots and genocides if no action taken
summary:
Facebook whistleblower Frances Haugen has said that events such as the January 6 riots and genocides in Myanmar and Ethopia are the “opening chapters” of worse events if action is not taken against the social media company.
Haugen gave the warning while giving evidence to UK Parliament.
“Facebook is prioritising growth over safety,” she said.
writtenSummary:
Facebook whistleblower Frances Haugen has said that events such as the January 6 riots and genocides in Myanmar and Ethopia are the “opening chapters” of worse events if action is not taken against the social media company.
Ms Haugen gave the warning while giving evidence to UK Parliament.
“Facebook is prioritising growth over safety,” she warned.

title: Hundreds refused entry creating vaccine passport "chaos" in Scotland
writtenTitle: Hundreds refused entry creating Vaccine Passport 'Chaos' in Scotland
summary:
The first weekend of enforcement of Scotland's vaccine passport scheme was an "unmitigated disaster", according to a body representing night-time venues.
There was no enforcement during a 17-day "grace period" as venues adjusted to the new requirements.
The scheme requires venues to put in place a "reasonable system" to check the status of customers.

The first weekend of enforcement of Scotland's vaccine passport scheme was an "unmitigated disaster", according to a body representing night-time venues.

The scheme requires venues to put in place a "reasonable system" to check the status of customers

title: Is HR ever really your friend?
writtenTitle: Is HR ever really your friend?
summary:
Employees often assume human resources is there to help. But given HR really works for the company, is it ever really on our side?
BBC reports there is a misconception, as HR departments are tasked with supporting the organisation, not employees.
In successful departments, HR is there to help the organisation achieve its ambitions.

title: Afghan baby girl sold for $500 by starving family
writtenTitle: Afghan baby girl sold for $500 by starving family
summary:
Afghanistan is facing the biggest humanitarian crisis in the world, with a sharp deterioration since the Taliban took over.
Estimates say 1 million children and babies are at risk of dying from malnutrition; public healthcare has collapsed after foreign aid was cut off.
Outside Herat, a mother sold one of her babies for 500 USD to feed her family.

title: Sudan's army declares state of emergency, dissolves government
writtenTitle: Sudan's army declares state of emergency, dissolves government
summary:
General Al-Burhan's announcement came after the coup in which armed forces detained figures of the govt in charge of leading the transition to democracy.
The coup came after weeks of tensions between the military and civilian figures sharing power since President Bashir's ouster.
The power grab was condemned by the international community.

General Al-Burhan's announcement came after the coup in which armed forces detained figures of the govt in charge of leading the transition to democracy.

The power grab was condemned by the international community.

title: Japan's Princess finally marries commoner boyfriend
writtenTitle: Japan's Princess finally marries commoner boyfriend
summary:
Princess Mako married her college sweetheart Kei Komuro, thus losing her royal status.
Under Japanese law, female imperial family members forfeit their status upon marriage to a commoner although male members do not.
She skipped the usual rites of a royal wedding and turned down a payment offered to royal females upon their departure from the family.
writtenSummary:
Princess Mako married her college sweetheart Kei Komuro, thus losing her royal status.

title: US releases new guidelines for international travel
writtenTitle: COVID: US releases new guidelines for international travel
summary:
The US will accept travelers who have received vaccines approved by the US FDA or authorised for emergency use by the WHO.
Travelers under the age of 18 will not be required to be fully vaccinated, due to the inconsistency in the rollout of vaccines for younger age groups.
However, they will be required to present a negative Covid test.
writtenSummary:
The US will accept travelers who have received vaccines approved by the US FDA or authorized for emergency use by the WHO.
Travelers under the age of 18 will not be required to be fully vaccinated, due to the inconsistency in the rollout of vaccines for younger age groups.
However, they will be required to present a negative COVID test.

title: Germany's nuclear power and energy price hikes
writtenTitle: Germany's nuclear power and energy price hikes
summary:
Energy prices are soaring globally and Germany's stock market price for electricity has risen by 140% since Jan.
This December, half of Germany's remaining nuclear reactors are scheduled to be taken offline and the other half is to cease operation next year.
This could potentially drive energy prices even higher as Germany also moves away from coal.
writtenSummary:
Energy prices are soaring globally and Germany's stock market price for electricity has risen by 140% since Jan.

This could potentially drive energy prices even higher as Germany also moves away from coal.

title: UN Security Council to discuss Sudan as three protesters killed
writtenTitle: UN Security Council to discuss Sudan as three protesters killed
summary:
The U.N. Security Council has scheduled an emergency closed-door meeting on the coup in Sudan.
Diplomats said late Monday that the consultations were requested by the United States, United Kingdom, France, Ireland, Norway and Estonia.
Washington is suspending $700 million in emergency assistance to Sudan following the coup.
writtenSummary:
The U.N. Security Council has scheduled an emergency closed-door meeting on the coup in Sudan.
Diplomats said late Monday that the consultations were requested by the United States, United Kingdom, France, Ireland, Norway, and Estonia.
Washington is suspending $700 million in emergency assistance to Sudan following the coup.

title: Australian children will need parental permission for Facebook
writtenTitle: Australian children will need parental permission for Facebook
summary:
Australian children under 16 will need parental permission to sign up to Facebook under proposed new laws; Instagram, and WhatsApp would also fall under the new requirements.
The new law aims to stop children's information being shared without consent.
Scientists have said the changes would allow for greater protection for social media users.
writtenSummary:

The new law aims to stop children's information being shared without consent
Scientists have said the changes would allow for greater protection for social media users.

title: Rishi Sunak unveils new spending pledges
writtenTitle: Rishi Sunak unveils new spending pledges
summary:
The chancellor has announced a series of spending pledges ahead of the autumn budget, which include £5bn for health research and £3bn for education.
Rishi Sunak has promised to do "whatever it takes" to support families with the cost of living.
He further promises £1.4bn to encourage foreign investment into UK businesses and attract overseas talent.

The chancellor has announced a series of spending pledges ahead of the autumn budget, which include £5bn for health research and £3bn for education

title: Amazon announces Alexa program for hospitals and senior care
writtenTitle: Amazon announces Alexa program for hospitals and senior care
summary:
Amazon has new programs that integrate Alexa into hospitals and senior living communities, the company said.
The program lets senior living facilities use Amazon Echo devices to send announcements or other messages to residents’ rooms.
Residents can also place calls through Alexa to family members or friends without having to rely on a staff member.
writtenSummary:
Amazon has new programs that integrate Alexa into hospitals and senior living communities, the company said.
The program lets senior living facilities use Amazon Echo devices to send announcements or other messages to residents’ rooms. 
Residents can also place calls through Alexa to family members or friends without having to rely on a staff member.

title: Mastercard expands crypto services with wallets, loyalty rewards
writtenTitle: Mastercard expands crypto services with wallets, loyalty rewards
summary:
Mastercard will allow its partners to enable their consumers to buy, sell and hold crypto using a digital wallet, and reward them with digital currencies under loyalty programs.
Mastercard will offer these services in partnership with Bakkt.
Last year, Visa had partnered with BlockFi to offer a credit card that lets users earn bitcoin on purchases.
writtenSummary:
Mastercard will allow its partners to enable their consumers to buy, sell and hold crypto using a digital wallet, and reward them with digital currencies under loyalty programs. 
Mastercard will offer these services in partnership with Bakkt. 
Last year, Visa had partnered with BlockFi to offer a credit card that lets users earn bitcoin on purchases.

title: Tesla keeps ignoring the government’s requests to fix Autopilot
writtenTitle: Tesla keeps ignoring the government’s requests to fix Autopilot
summary:
NTSB is not happy with Tesla’s failure to respond to its safety recommendations made four years ago concerning the company’s controversial driver assist feature.
Tesla’s failure to respond has led to additional crashes and further safety lapses, NTSB said.
NTSB can conduct investigations and make recommendations but has no enforcement authority.
