Squid is known as a "play-to-earn" cryptocurrency, where people buy tokens to play in online games where they can earn more tokens.

title: Menopause: HRT prescription costs to fall, says government
writtenTitle: Menopause: HRT prescription costs to fall, says government
summary:
The cost of Hormone Replacement Therapy prescriptions will fall after a campaign by a Labour MP.
Carolyn Harris put forward a bill in Parliament to make the menopause treatment free in England.
The government would not go that far, but said women would only have to pay for the prescription once a year - saving upwards of £200 annually.
writtenSummary:
The cost of Hormone Replacement Therapy prescriptions will fall after a campaign by a Labour MP.
Carolyn Harris put forward a bill in Parliament to make the menopause treatment free in England.
The government would not go that far, but said women would only have to pay for the prescription once a year - saving upwards of £200 annually.

title: Insulate Britain: Arrests as protesters walk alongside M25 traffic
writtenTitle: Insulate Britain: Arrests as protesters walk alongside M25 traffic
summary:
Insulate Britain protesters caused delays on the M25 by walking alongside oncoming traffic.
Essex Police was called to a stretch of the motorway between junctions 28 and 29 near Great Warley and 10 arrests were made.
The protest group said the decision to stop sitting in the middle of roads had been made keeping frustrated drivers’ feedback in mind.
writtenSummary:
Insulate Britain protesters caused delays on the M25 by walking alongside oncoming traffic.
Essex Police was called to a stretch of the motorway between junctions 28 and 29 near Great Warley and 10 arrests were made.
The protest group said the decision to stop sitting in the middle of roads had been made keeping frustrated drivers’ feedback in mind.

title: Amazon to pay billions to prevent Christmas labour shortages
writtenTitle: Amazon to pay billions to prevent Christmas labour shortages
summary:
Amazon has said it will spend several billion dollars to manage labour shortages and supply chain issues in the run-up to Christmas.
The online retail giant said it was doing "whatever it takes to minimise the impact" on customers and sellers.
Meanwhile, Apple said a shortage of semiconductor chips had cost it $6bn (£4.35bn) in lost sales.
writtenSummary:
Amazon has said it will spend several billion dollars to manage labour shortages and supply chain issues in the run-up to Christmas.
The online retail giant said it was doing "whatever it takes to minimise the impact" on customers and sellers.
Meanwhile, Apple said a shortage of semiconductor chips had cost it $6bn (£4.35bn) in lost sales.

title: This moon motorcycle concept by an automotive designer is wild
writtenTitle: This moon motorcycle concept by an automotive designer is just wild
summary:
Moscow-based automotive designer Andrew has created a concept design for a lunar motorcycle and hopes to build a full-size prototype.
According to Andrew, the idea came about following a challenge on Instagram.
The main design theme of this motorcycle is to make an object that looks like clear engineering, with minimum styling elements, Andrew said.
writtenSummary:
Moscow-based automotive designer Andrew has created a concept design for a lunar motorcycle and hopes to build a full-size prototype.
According to Andrew, the idea came about following a challenge on Instagram. 
The main design theme of this motorcycle is to make an object that looks like clear engineering, with minimum styling elements, Andrew said.

title: What would happen if an asteroid were going to hit Earth?
writtenTitle: What would happen if an asteroid were going to hit Earth?
summary:
With NASA's DART asteroid deflection mission about to launch, this question is hot on many people's minds.
The spacecraft will eventually slam into a small asteroid orbiting a larger asteroid to see if the manoeuvre will change its course so it orbits closer.
The eventual goal for this mission is to test potential asteroid-diverting technologies.
writtenSummary:
With NASA's DART asteroid deflection mission about to launch, this question is hot on many people's minds. 
The spacecraft will eventually slam into a small asteroid orbiting a larger asteroid to see if the manoeuvre will change its course so it orbits closer. 
The eventual goal for this mission is to test potential asteroid-diverting technologies.

title: The Wharton School will let students pay in bitcoin
writtenTitle: The Wharton School will let students pay in bitcoin
summary:
The prestigious business school at the University of Pennsylvania will soon accept cryptocurrencies as payment for its new series of blockchain classes.
The classes are designed for a variety of professionals in fields such as finance, management and tech.
Among the Wharton School's vast alumni network is Tesla chief Elon Musk, who graduated in 1997.
writtenSummary:
The prestigious business school at the University of Pennsylvania will soon accept cryptocurrencies as payment for its new series of blockchain classes.
The classes are designed for a variety of professionals in fields such as finance, management and tech.
Among the Wharton School's vast alumni network is Tesla chief Elon Musk, who graduated in 1997.

title: Ether climbs to an all-time high, what's driving the rally?
writtenTitle: Ether climbs to an all-time high. What's driving the rally?
summary:
Ether climbed to an all-time high amid surging use of the Ethereum network for everything from NFTs to decentralised-finance applications.
The milestone follows an all-time peak for Bitcoin last week of almost $67,000.
Ethereum has long passed Bitcoin as the most used blockchain; more than 3,000 decentralized apps run on the Ethereum blockchain.
writtenSummary:
Ether climbed to an all-time high amid surging use of the Ethereum network for everything from NFTs to decentralized-finance applications. 
The milestone follows an all-time peak for Bitcoin last week of almost $67,000. 
Ethereum has long passed Bitcoin as the most used blockchain; more than 3,000 decentralized apps run on the Ethereum blockchain.

title: France moves to shield local bookstores from Amazon
writtenTitle: France moves to shield local bookstores from Amazon
summary:
France's bookshop has survived the rise of Amazon due to the law that prohibits price discounting on new books.
But the e-commerce giant's ability to undercut shipping still skews the market against stores.
Amazon said the legislation, adopted by parliament but not yet enacted, would punish those who cannot visit a bookstore and rely on delivery.
writtenSummary:
France's bookshop has survived the rise of Amazon due to the law that prohibits price discounting on new books.
But the e-commerce giant's ability to undercut shipping still skews the market against stores.
Amazon said the legislation, adopted by parliament but not yet enacted, would punish those who cannot visit a bookstore and rely on delivery.

title: UK Covid boosters outstripping first jabs in Africa per capita
writtenTitle: UK Covid boosters outstripping first jabs in Africa per capita
summary:
According to the latest data more people have received a Covid booster vaccination in the UK per head of population than are reported to have had their first shot in Africa.
Data shows the extent of vaccine inequality between high and low-income countries.
The UK was accused of lagging behind in sharing surplus Covid vaccines with poorer countries.

writtenTitle: India: 100 million people fail to turn up for second Covid vaccine
summary:
The data raises fears of a resurgence in the spread of coronavirus despite daily cases reaching their lowest for months.
India has administered first doses to 725 million people of its’ 944 million adults, and second doses to 316 million.
Experts are wondering if giving the second dose might prove to be even more of a challenge.

title: Pakistan: Media regulator accused of 'moral policing'
writtenTitle: Pakistan: Media regulator accused of 'moral policing'
summary:
The Pakistani government's media watchdog has imposed a ban on "intimate" scenes on television amid growing religious conservativism in the country.
Rights activists have decried the move, saying the govt is trying to divert attention from society’s real issues.
Supporters of govt believe it is the right move to protect Islamic values.
writtenSummary:
The Pakistani government's media watchdog has imposed a ban on "intimate" scenes on television amid growing religious conservativism in the country.

Supporters of govt believe it is the right move to protect Islamic values.

title: Germany: Majority want autobahn speed limits
writtenTitle: Germany: Majority want autobahn speed limits
summary:
A survey shows that most people in Germany are in favour of abandoning the highways with no speed limit.
It found that curbing highway speeds was a much more popular piece of climate policy than other options, such as taxing meat and dairy products.
Germany's next govt would appear out of step with the public on this key issue.
writtenSummary:
A survey shows that most people in Germany are in favour of abandoning the highways with no speed limit.
It found that curbing highway speeds was a much more popular piece of climate policy than other options, such as taxing meat and dairy products.
Germany's likely next govt would appear out of step with the public on this key issue.

title: Israeli plans in the West Bank draw condemnation from US, UK, Europe
writtenTitle: Israeli plans in the West Bank draw condemnation from US, UK, Europe
summary:
Israel's plan to greenlight thousands of new Israeli housing units in the West Bank is drawing outcry from the US, UK and a dozen European countries.
The move is likely to create tensions locally and globally.
The timing of the announcement is also being criticized at home by left and center-left parties in Israel's governing coalition.
writtenSummary:
Israel's plan to greenlight thousands of new Israeli housing units in the West Bank is drawing outcry from the US, UK, and a dozen European countries.
The move is likely to create tensions locally and globally. 
The timing of the announcement is also being criticized at home by left and center-left parties in Israel's governing coalition.

title: Myanmar junta sentences aide of Aung San Suu Kyi
writtenTitle: Myanmar junta sentences aide of Aung San Suu Kyi
summary:
The military junta sentenced Win Htein, a close aide of ousted civilian leader Suu Kyi to 20 yrs in prison for treason.
He is a longtime political prisoner, who has spent long stretches of time in and out of detention for campaigning against military rule.
Ahead of his arrest three days after the coup, he said the military putsch was not wise.
writtenSummary:
The military junta sentenced Win Htein, a close aide of ousted civilian leader Suu Kyi to 20 yrs in prison for treason.
He is a longtime political prisoner, who has spent long stretches of time in and out of detention for campaigning against military rule.
Ahead of his arrest three days after the coup, he told that the military putsch was not wise.

title: England to prescribe e-cigarettes for those who want to stop smoking
writtenTitle: England to prescribe e-cigarettes for those who want to stop smoking
summary:
E-cigarettes could be prescribed by England's National Health Service under plans to cut smoking rates in the country.
The UK's Regulatory Agency MHRA is publishing guidance that could allow e-cigarette products to be prescribed for those who want to stop smoking.
Manufacturers of e-cigarette products can now approach the MHRA with their products.
writtenSummary:
E-cigarettes could be prescribed by England's National Health Service under plans to cut smoking rates in the country.
The UK's Regulatory Agency MHRA is publishing guidance that could allow e-cigarette products to be prescribed for those who want to stop smoking.

title: Half of Syria was displaced by war, now drought threatens millions
writtenTitle: Half of Syria was displaced by war. Now drought threatens millions
summary:
After the horrors of civil war and ISIS, millions of Syrians face drought.
Drought, worsened by a warming climate, drove Syrian farmers to abandon their crops and flock to cities.
Zwijnenburg, who works for PAX, says they are witnessing is a potential ecological collapse in northeast Syria from climate-caused and conflict linked environmental damage.
writtenSummary:
After the horrors of civil war and Isis, millions of Syrians face drought.
Drought, worsened by a warming climate, drove Syrian farmers to abandon their crops and flock to cities. 
Previous droughts in Syria are linked to the civil war. Historically droughts in the country are described as multi-year droughts. In 2006 a drought lasted until 2010.
keywords: drought threatens millions Half Syria displaced war warming climate, drove Syrian farmers Syrians face drought Isis, millions Drought, worsened drought lasted Previous droughts Historically droughts civil war 2006 2010 horrors abandon crops flock cities Syria linked country multi-year droughts

title: Exercise can reduce students' desire to drink alcohol
writtenTitle: Exercise can reduce students' desire to drink alcohol
summary:
Alcohol intoxication is increasingly regarded as socially acceptable behaviour, and excessive alcohol consumption was identified as a significant problem among university students.
45-69% of UK students engage in weekly binge drinking sessions.
Research found that students who exercise are less likely to crave alcohol and can feel more positive.
writtenSummary:
Alcohol intoxication is increasingly regarded as socially acceptable behaviour, and excessive alcohol consumption was identified as a significant problem among university students. 
45-69% of UK students engage in weekly binge drinking sessions.

writtenTitle: Outcry after Oklahoma prisoner vomits and convulses during execution
summary:
Oklahoma is coming under sharp criticism after witnesses described gruesome scenes of the dying prisoner convulsing and vomiting as he was administered the lethal injections.
John Grant, 60, was pronounced dead at McAlester state penitentiary after the state’s first judicial killing for six years.
Grant was injected with a triple deadly cocktail.

title: Sudan coup leader pledges to appoint new premier within week
writtenTitle: Sudan coup leader pledges to appoint new premier within week
summary:
The Sudanese general who seized power in a coup this week said the military he heads will appoint a “technocrat” prime minister to rule alongside it within days.
The coup has derailed a transition meant to steer Sudan to democracy, with elections in 2023.
The coup has elicited a storm of street protests demanding the restoration of a civilian gov't.
writtenSummary:
The Sudanese general who seized power in a coup this week said the military he heads will appoint a “technocrat” prime minister to rule alongside it within days. 
The coup has derailed a transition meant to steer Sudan to democracy, with elections in 2023.
The coup has elicited a storm of street protests demanding the restoration of a civilian gov't.

title: Saudi Arabia, Bahrain expel Lebanese ambassadors
writtenTitle: Saudi Arabia, Bahrain expel Lebanese ambassadors
summary:
The diplomatic feud comes days after footage emerged of Lebanon’s information minister criticising the Saudi-led war in Yemen.
Saudi Arabia has banned all imports from Lebanon and given the Lebanese ambassador 48 hours to leave the kingdom.
Hours later, Bahrain ordered the Lebanese ambassador to leave the country within two days for the same reason.

title: UN renews peacekeeping mission in Western Sahara, calls for talks
writtenTitle: UN renews peacekeeping mission in Western Sahara, calls for talks
summary:
The UNSC resolution expresses concern over the breakdown of the ceasefire between Morocco and the pro-independence Polisario Front.
Morocco has proposed wide-ranging autonomy for Western Sahara, but the Polisario Front insists the local population has the right to a referendum on independence.
Algeria backs the independence-seeking Polisario Front.
writtenSummary:
The UNSC resolution expresses concern over the breakdown of the ceasefire between Morocco and the pro-independence Polisario Front.

Algeria backs the independence-seeking Polisario Front.

title: Greek PM voices concern over West’s stance towards Turkey
writtenTitle: Greek PM voices concern over West’s stance towards Turkey
summary:
Mitsotakis has said he is concerned that Western powers’ response towards Turkish actions is encouraging it to behave in an unacceptable manner.
Neighbours and NATO allies Greece and Turkey are at odds over a series of issues, including territorial disputes and Cyprus.
Mitsotakis’s comments came after a meeting with outgoing German Chancellor Merkel.

title: Americas' COVID cases are down, vaccine inequity still a problem
writtenTitle: Americas COVID cases are down, vaccine inequity still a problem
summary:
New COVID cases and deaths in the Americas have reached the lowest levels in over a year.
Despite overall decreases in COVID cases and deaths, smaller islands, such as Saint Kitts and Nevis, Barbados, Anguilla and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines are just reaching their first pandemic peaks.
Only 44% of people in the Americas are fully vaccinated.
writtenSummary:
New COVID cases and deaths in the Americas have reached the lowest levels in over a year. 
Despite overall decreases in COVID cases and deaths, smaller islands, such as Saint Kitts and Nevis, Barbados, Anguilla and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines are just reaching their first pandemic peaks. 
Only 44% of people in the Americas are fully vaccinated.

title: Greta Thunberg joins London protest
writtenTitle: COP26: Greta Thunberg joins London protest
summary:
Swedish environmental activist Greta Thunberg joined a small group of dozen young people protesting in front of Standard Chartered Bank in London.
Protesters say banks are profiting off of environmental destruction by funding the fossil fuel industry.
Organizers say similar protests were being staged in 26 countries around the world.

title: Scotland first in world to use new diabetes test
writtenTitle: Scotland first in world to use new diabetes test
summary:
Some Type 1 diabetes patients could be freed from the need to take insulin after a new test is introduced.
Scotland will become the first country in the world to use the simple C-peptide blood test.
The test finds out how much insulin a patient's body is producing, the test will be available from clinics from 1 November.
writtenSummary:
Some Type 1 diabetes patients could be freed from the need to take insulin after a new test is introduced.
Scotland will become the first country in the world to use the simple C-peptide blood test.
The test finds out how much insulin a patient's body is producing, the test will be available from clinics from 1 November.

title: Macron: Fishing row a test of UK's credibility
writtenTitle: Macron: Fishing row a test of UK's credibility
summary:
Emmanuel Macron raised tensions with Britain by warning that the dispute over fishing rights is a test of the UK's global credibility.
He spoke out ahead of the G20 summit in Rome, which sets the stage for the COP26 climate summit.
France and the UK are embroiled in a dispute over post-Brexit fishing rights and licences for French boats.
writtenSummary:
Emmanuel Macron raised tensions with Britain by warning that the dispute over fishing rights is a test of the UK's global credibility.
He spoke out ahead of the G20 summit in Rome, which sets the stage for the COP26 climate summit.
France and the UK are embroiled in a dispute over post-Brexit fishing rights and licences for French boats.

title: Covid: Work train journeys less than half pre-pandemic
writtenTitle: Covid: Work train journeys less than half pre-pandemic
summary:
The number of commuter journeys by train remain at less than half of pre-pandemic levels, figures show.
Trips made by made by people going to or from work on the UK's railways in mid-October was 45% of what it was before autumn 2019, says industry body the Rail Delivery Group (RDG).
It comes as many people continue to work from home.
writtenSummary:
The number of commuter journeys by train remain at less than half of pre-pandemic levels, figures show.
Trips made by made by people going to or from work on the UK's railways in mid-October was 45% of what it was before autumn 2019, says industry body the Rail Delivery Group (RDG).
It comes as many people continue to work from home.

title: Wales v New Zealand: Covid passes for all at Principality Stadium
writtenTitle: Wales v New Zealand: Covid passes for all at Principality Stadium
summary:
Covid passes will be needed for all 74,000 fans on Saturday as Wales hosts international rugby at a full stadium for the first time since the pandemic.
Each ticket holder will also have an arrival time at a specific gate to stagger entries at the Principality Stadium in Cardiff.
The passes had been well managed at big football matches in Wales.

Covid passes will be needed for all 74,000 fans on Saturday as Wales hosts international rugby at a full stadium for the first time since the pandemic.

The passes had been well managed at big football matches in Wales.

title: Sir Elton John hits number one with lockdown album
writtenTitle: Sir Elton John hits number one with lockdown album
summary:
Sir Elton John scored his 8th UK number one album with his Covid-enforced surprise album The Lockdown Sessions.
Recorded when his farewell tour was postponed by the pandemic, the record features collaborations with Dua Lipa, Stevie Nicks, Gorillaz and Lil Nas X.
Many duets took place over Zoom, while others took place in the studio.
writtenSummary:
Sir Elton John scored his 8th UK number one album with his Covid-enforced surprise album The Lockdown Sessions.
Recorded when his farewell tour was postponed by the pandemic, the record features collaborations with Dua Lipa, Stevie Nicks, Gorillaz and Lil Nas X.
Many duets took place over Zoom, while others took place in the studio.

title: Poland: Lawmakers approve Belarus border wall amid migrant surge
writtenTitle: Poland: Lawmakers approve Belarus border wall amid migrant surge
summary:
Poland's parliament approved the construction of a hard wall along the Belarus border to stem the tide of migration into the country. 
The wall is expected to cost an estimated €353 million and will span more than 100 km.
Poland says the wall is essential to "protect" the country, whereas opposition parties refer to it as a "wall".
writtenSummary:
Poland's parliament approved the construction of a hard wall along the Belarus border to stem the tide of migration into the country. 
The wall is expected to cost an estimated €353 million and will span more than 100 km.
Poland says the wall is essential to "protect" the country, whereas opposition parties refer to it as a "wall".

title: India successfully test first indigenously developed long-range bomb
writtenTitle: India successfully test first indigenously developed long-range bomb
summary:
Indian Air Force (IAF) and the Defence Research and Development Organisation (DRDO) successfully flight-tested the country’s first indigenously developed LRB from a fighter jet over Balasore in Odisha.
The bomb is part of a class of weapons with a range of 50 - 150 km.
The govt shared details that the weapon was tested from an aerial platform.
writtenSummary:
Indian Air Force (IAF) and the Defence Research and Development Organisation (DRDO) successfully flight-tested the country’s first indigenously developed LRB from a fighter jet over Balasore in Odisha.
The bomb is part of the class of weapons with a range of 50 - 150 km. 
The govt shared details that the weapon was tested from an aerial platform.

title: Uzbekistan: Pre-school education goes mobile
writtenTitle: Pre-school education in goes mobile
summary:
Dozens of mobile pre-school buses travel across the country and they are one of several new initiatives to give all Uzbek children access to pre-school education.
The govt made a significant push for reform and now over 60% of the children receive an education.
The country’s recent innovations in pre-schooling and their impact are far-reaching.
writtenSummary:
Dozens of mobile pre-school buses travel across the country and they are one of several new initiatives to give all Uzbek children access to pre-school education.
The govt made a significant push for reform and now over 60% of the children receive an education.

title: Eurozone inflation hits 13-year high amid persistent energy crunch
writtenTitle: Eurozone inflation hits 13-year high amid persistent energy crunch
summary:
The data from Eurostat shows inflation in the eurozone hitting 4.1% – the highest figure since the Great Recession.
It is almost double the 2.2% annual estimation of the European Central Bank (ECB).
Prices across the 19-nation euro area have risen at a rapid pace since countries began lifting coronavirus restrictions.
writtenSummary:
The data from Eurostat shows inflation in the eurozone hitting 4.1% – the highest figure since the Great Recession.
It is almost double the 2.2% annual estimation of the European Central Bank (ECB).
Prices across the 19-nation euro area have risen at a rapid pace since countries began lifting coronavirus restrictions.

title: Greece: Cargo ship with migrants onboard rescued after engine problem
writtenTitle: Greece: Cargo ship with migrants onboard rescued after engine problem
summary:
A ship with 400 migrants on board is headed to a safe anchorage in Greece after suffering engine problems off the island of Crete.
The ship would likely have been heading for Italy where smuggling rings frequently send migrants by the sea.
There was no immediate indication of the passengers' health or nationalities.
writtenSummary:
A ship with 400 migrants on board is headed to a safe anchorage in Greece after suffering engine problems off the island of Crete.
The ship would likely have been heading for Italy where smuggling rings frequently send migrants by the sea.
There was no immediate indication of the passengers' health or nationalities.

title: 8 people jailed in Russia over deadly Kemerovo leisure centre fire
writtenTitle: 8 people jailed in Russia over deadly Kemerovo leisure centre fire
summary:
A Russian court has jailed eight people for negligence over the deadly 2018 fire at a leisure centre in Kemerovo that killed sixty people.
Lengthy prison sentences were handed out to the manager of the building, as well as fire safety officers.
An investigation concluded that the company that owned the mall had violated fire safety regulations.
writtenSummary:
A Russian court has jailed eight people for negligence over the deadly 2018 fire at a leisure centre in Kemerovo that killed sixty people.
Lengthy prison sentences were handed out to the manager of the building, as well as fire safety officers.
An investigation concluded that the company that owned the mall had violated fire safety regulations.

title: Canada challenges compensation order for indigenous children
writtenTitle: Canada challenges compensation order for indigenous children
summary:
Canada will appeal against a court order to pay billions of dollars to compensate indigenous children who underwent the child welfare system.
The govt said it had issues over the order's jurisdiction and how the money was to be divided.
Last month, a court upheld a 2016 ruling that the govt underfunded First Nations services.
writtenSummary:
Canada will appeal against a court order to pay billions of dollars to compensate indigenous children who underwent the child welfare system.
The govt said it had issues over the order's jurisdiction and how the money was to be divided.
Last month, a court upheld a 2016 ruling that the govt underfunded First Nations services.

title: US intelligence agencies say Covid-19 origins may never be known
writtenTitle: US intelligence agencies say Covid-19 origins may never be known
summary:
The US says they may never be able to identify the origins of Covid, but they have concluded it was not created as a biological weapon.
The Office of the US Director of National Intelligence said an animal-to-human transmission and a lab leak were both plausible hypotheses.
There was not enough information to reach a definitive conclusion.
writtenSummary:
The US says they may never be able to identify the origins of Covid, but they have concluded it was not created as a biological weapon.
The Office of the US Director of National Intelligence said an animal-to-human transmission and a lab leak were both plausible hypotheses.
There was not enough information to reach a definitive conclusion.

title: Tonga records first coronavirus case since start of pandemic
writtenTitle: Tonga records first coronavirus case since start of pandemic
summary:
The infected individual was among 215 people on a repatriation flight from Christchurch, New Zealand.
Others onboard included members of Tonga's Olympic team who had been stranded in the city since the Tokyo Olympics.
New Zealand's health ministry said that the individual had tested negative before leaving the country.
writtenSummary:
The infected individual was among 215 people on a repatriation flight from Christchurch, New Zealand.
Others onboard included members of Tonga's Olympic team who had been stranded in the city since the Tokyo Olympics.
New Zealand's health ministry said that the individual had tested negative before leaving the country.

title: La Palma: Living with lava
writtenTitle: La Palma: Living with lava
summary:
The Canary Islands are a volcanic archipelago off the coast of Africa.
The most north-westerly island, La Palma, is one of the most active volcanoes in the world.
The Cumbre Vieja volcano, which erupted in 1949, has been erupting since 23rd June 2017, causing severe damage to the Canary Islands' architecture and agriculture.
writtenSummary:

The most north-westerly island, La Palma, is one of the most active volcanoes in the world.
The Cumbre Vieja volcano, which erupted in 1949, has been erupting since 23rd June 2017, causing severe damage to the Canary Islands' architecture and agriculture.

title: G20: Climate and Covid top agenda as world leaders meet
writtenTitle: G20: Climate and Covid top agenda as world leaders meet
summary:
Climate change and Covid are top of the agenda as leaders from the world's major economies meet in Italy.
China's Xi Jinping and Russia's Vladimir Putin will not be in Rome for the summit, choosing to appear via video link instead.
A draft communiqué outlines a promise from the G20 to work towards limiting the rise in temperatures to 1.5C (2.7F).
writtenSummary:
Climate change and Covid are top of the agenda as leaders from the world's major economies meet in Italy.
China's Xi Jinping and Russia's Vladimir Putin will not be in Rome for the summit, choosing to appear via video link instead.
A draft communiqué outlines a promise from the G20 to work towards limiting the rise in temperatures to 1.5C (2.7F).

title: Whole country wishes Queen well: Boris Johnson
writtenTitle: Whole country wishes Queen well - Boris Johnson
summary:
The Queen will not attend the COP26 climate change summit in Glasgow as previously planned.
Her planned address to delegates attending COP26 will be played via video at the event.
Recent cancellations have been described as a "wake-up call that the Queen is 95", with Royal correspondents citing ‘fatigue not illness’ as the cause of her absence.

Her planned address to delegates attending COP26 will be played via video at the event.
 Recent cancellations have been described as a "wake-up call that the Queen is 95", with Royal correspondents citing ‘fatigue not illness’ as the cause of her absence.

title: Demonstrators protest French presence in Mali on Bamako streets
writtenTitle: Demonstrators protest French presence in Mali on Bamako streets
summary:
Protesters took to the streets of Bamako to demonstrate against the French military in Mali, calling for the total withdrawal of French troops from the country.
Tension prevails between Mali and France over reports Bamako could recruit Russian mercenaries.
The report came as Paris reshapes its 5,000-strong counter-terrorism mission in the region.

title: US criticised for withholding economic aid to Sudan
writtenTitle: U.S. criticised for withholding economic aid to Sudan
summary:
The US suspended $700 million in aid to Sudan after the country’s military forces arrested civilian leaders.
Sudan officials said they should be punished for what occurred in the previous regime under former President Al-Bashir.
The capital Khartoum has been witnessing street demonstrations demanding a civilian government.

title: Ethiopia: War leaves two-thirds of sesame farm uncultivated
writtenTitle: Ethiopia: War leaves two-thirds of sesame farm uncultivated
summary:
500,000 hectares of sesame farm, which is 70% of Ethiopia's annual cultivation for the cash crop, skipped a season without being cultivated due to the ongoing war.
Farmers from these areas currently need humanitarian aid. 
Ethiopia’s sesame farms have already been thinning after Sudan occupied 40 km in Gondar, fertile land for sesame production.

title: Japan ports swamped by pumice spewed from undersea volcano
writtenTitle: Japan ports swamped by pumice spewed from undersea volcano
summary:
Pumice pebbles, spewed out by an undersea volcano, have clogged dozens of ports and damaged boats along Japan’s southernmost coast.
There had been a huge impact on the fisheries, tourism, and environment.
Govt task force is to provide support for local municipalities as a disaster recovery project, as the pebbles could affect entire Japanese coasts.

title: How easy is it to drive from London to Glasgow using an electric car?
writtenTitle: How easy is it to drive from London to Glasgow using an electric car?
summary:
It was at my first charging stop that I realised driving an electric car might not be as straightforward as I had thought, Sky News' Moore said.
Zap-Map says the UK has just over 26,600 chargers, but a report found 1 in 25 of those aren't working at any given time on average.
Cars are one of the four areas PM Johnson has promised action on at COP26.

title: UK: Christmas will be lockdown-free despite rising Covid cases
writtenTitle: Christmas will be lockdown-free despite rising COVID cases, PM says
summary:
Johnson said that, despite rising Covid-19 cases, he has seen no evidence to indicate a Christmas lockdown is "on the cards".
Hospitalisations and deaths remain well below the levels seen earlier this year, in part due to the vaccine rollout.
Johnson urged the over-50s to get the booster jab, warning the effects of the first two doses do wane.

Hospitalisations and deaths remain well below the levels seen earlier this year - in part due to the vaccine rollout.
Johnson again urged the over-50s to get the booster jab, warning the effects of the first two doses do wane.

title: Teenager arrested after swastikas sprayed on London synagogue
writtenTitle: Teenager arrested after swastikas sprayed on London synagogue
summary:
Police were alerted to reports of someone spraying swastikas on the walls of a synagogue in Camden at about 7.40 pm on Saturday.
Officers found a 16-year-old boy nearby shortly after 8 pm and arrested him on suspicion of religiously aggravated criminal damage.
Police said they also found other swastikas sprayed on walls in the surrounding area.

writtenTitle: NHS to visit hundreds of schools to offer COVID vaccine to under-15s

Thousands of under-15s will be offered the jab at school, with NHS teams visiting over 800 schools.
The government is making a push to get as many people vaccinated before the winter months set in.
On Oct 29, the SAGE said the high number of cases in schools where only some are vaccinated "provide the ideal conditions" for a new variant to emerge.

writtenTitle: COP26: Antarctic glacier is named in honour of Glasgow
summary:
A previously unnamed glacier is to be called Glasgow Glacier to mark the city's hosting of the COP26 meeting.
8 other glaciers will also carry the names of cities where important climate reports were issued, or policies were agreed.
Scientists said they wanted the glaciers to be a symbol of what was at stake in Glasgow over the next couple of weeks.

writtenTitle: La Liga denounces racist insults against Vinícius Junior
summary:
The Spanish league has denounced racist insults by a Barcelona fan against Real Madrid's Vinícius Júnior during the “clásico” at the Camp Nou Stadium on October 24.
The 21-year-old Brazil international started and played most of the game.
Last year, the league condemned racist insults by Espanyol fans against Athletic Bilbao forward Iñaki Williams.

title: Spain is planning high-speed trains between London and Paris
writtenTitle: Spain is planning high-speed trains between London and Paris
summary:
Spain's national railway company Renfe says they expect the route to be profitable; 9 mn passengers took trains between London and Paris in 2019.
The move will make them a direct competitor of Eurostar who has run trains between the two capitals since 1994.
The decision comes as France's state-owned railway operator SNCF enters the Spanish market.

title: Man dies after being gored at bull-running festival in Spain
writtenTitle: Man dies after being gored at bull-running festival in Spain
summary:
It was the first related fatality in the nation since such events resumed following a Covid hiatus.
Other participants tried to entice the animal away but their efforts failed.
A 2020 survey found 46.7% of Spaniards were in favour of banning bullfighting, 34.7% were not in favour but did not back a legal ban and 18.6% believed it should be preserved.

title: Afghanistan: Gunmen attack wedding to stop music being played
writtenTitle: Afghanistan: Gunmen attack wedding to stop music being played
summary:
Gunmen who identified themselves as Taliban attacked a wedding in eastern Afghanistan to stop music being played.
At least two people have been killed and 10 others injured, officials say.
The Taliban said two of the three gunmen had been arrested but denied they had acted on behalf of the Islamist movement.
writtenSummary:
Gunmen who identified themselves as Taliban attacked a wedding in eastern Afghanistan to stop music being played.
At least two people have been killed and and 10 others injured, officials say.
The Taliban said two of the three gunmen had been arrested but denied they had acted on behalf of the Islamist movement.

title: Intelligence agencies admit the origins of Covid-19 may never be known
writtenTitle: Intelligence agencies admit the origins of COVID-19 may never be known
summary:
The Office of the US Director of National Intelligence (ODNI) said on Friday that theories involving transmission from animals or a leak from a lab were plausible.
The office added that analysts could not agree which was more likely or if any firm conclusion could be made at all.
They dismissed suggestions that the virus originated as a bioweapon.
writtenSummary:
The Office of the US Director of National Intelligence (ODNI) said on Friday that theories involving transmission from animals or a leak from a lab were plausible.
The office added that analysts could not agree which was more likely or if any firm conclusion could be made at all.
They dismissed suggestions that the virus originated as a bioweapon.

title: Man charged for trying to sell a 4,500-year-old meteorite fragment
writtenTitle: Man charged for trying to sell a 4,500-year-old meteorite fragment
summary:
A fragment of a meteorite that landed in the village of Reliegos, near Leon in northern Spain in 1947, was offered for sale on the internet for €50,000.
The suspect was arrested after the rock was put up for sale on todocoleccion.net earlier this year.
The meteorite fragment will now go on show at the Spanish Museum of Natural Sciences.
writtenSummary:
A fragment of a meteorite that landed in the village of Reliegos, near Leon in northern Spain in 1947, was offered for sale on the internet for €50,000. 
The suspect was arrested after the rock was put up for sale on todocoleccion.net, a website, earlier this year. 
The meteorite fragment will now go on show at the Spanish Museum of Natural Sciences.

But the US remains obsessed with political manipulation and intelligence-led origins tracing in disregard of international justice.

title: India: The village that could disappear underwater in AP
writtenTitle: India: The village that could disappear underwater in AP
summary:
Uppada, a coastal village in Andhra Pradesh, known for its unique weaving tradition is under threat due to rising sea levels.
Several people have been displaced as coastal erosion has broken their houses and damaged properties.
Climate researchers say the neighbouring city of Kakinada, just 16 miles away, could also be submerged in 80 yrs.

Climate researchers say the neighbouring city of Kakinada, just 16 miles away, could also be submerged in 80 yrs.

The announcement by the TPLF came a day after it claimed control of Dessie.
The conflict in Kombolcha, south of Dessie, has fired speculation that the TPLF was heading closer to the Ethiopian capital Addis Ababa.

title: G20 leaders make mild pledges on carbon neutrality and coal financing
writtenTitle: G20 leaders make mild pledges on carbon neutrality and coal financing
summary:
Leaders of the world’s biggest economies made a commitment to reach carbon neutrality by or around mid-century at the G20 summit.
They agreed to end public financing for coal-fired power generation abroad but set no target for phasing out coal domestically.
G20 countries represent more than three-quarters of the world's greenhouse gas emissions.

title: Turkey’s President Erdogan to skip COP26 climate summit
writtenTitle: Turkey’s President Erdogan to skip COP26 climate summit
summary:
Turkey has ratified the Paris climate agreement, meaning it is now legally bound to meet its emissions reduction goals.
They plan to reduce emissions by 21% by 2030, reaching net-zero emissions by 2053.
Turkey currently accounts for less than 1% of global emissions, experts say this mainly comes from energy use derived from coal and non-renewables.

title: Can carbon capture facilities reverse climate change?
writtenTitle: Can carbon capture facilities reverse climate change?
summary:
The world’s biggest complex in Iceland will capture 4,000 tonnes of greenhouse gas per year in boxes the size of shipping containers.
Scientists are touting this cutting-edge yet costly technology as a key solution to the climate crisis.
Its fiercest critics brand it a naive and unproven tactic that offers the worst polluters a smokescreen.

writtenTitle: Biden, Erdogan discuss F-16 fighter jets and human rights
summary:
The leaders met amid tensions between the two countries over defence and human rights issues.
Biden reaffirmed the defence partnership and Turkey’s importance as a NATO ally.
He also emphasised the importance of strong democratic institutions, respect for human rights, and the rule of law for peace and prosperity.

title: Anger after Italian bill to fight homophobia rejected
writtenTitle: Anger after Italian bill to fight homophobia rejected
summary:
For many in Italy’s LGBT+ community, the rejection of a bill meant to ban discrimination was viewed as a step backward on the already-fraught road to equality.
The bill would have amended Italy’s penal code to ban discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation.
Transphobic hate crimes are widespread in Italy, which tops other European countries.

title: Boris Johnson talks about climate change ahead of the COP26
writtenTitle: Boris Johnson talks about climate change ahead of the COP26
summary:
The world is at "one minute to midnight", having run down the clock on waiting to combat climate change, the UK PM said.
He was speaking as world leaders arrived for the landmark COP26 climate change conference in Glasgow.
Boris Johnson said leaders needed to move from "aspiration to action" in an effort to slow global warming.
writtenSummary:
The world is at "one minute to midnight", having run down the clock on waiting to combat climate change, the UK PM said.

Boris Johnson said leaders needed to move from "aspiration to action" to slow global warming.

title: ‘The island is shrinking’: living on the frontline of global heating
writtenTitle: ‘The island is shrinking’: living on the frontline of global heating
summary:
25 years ago, Ghoramara island India began eroding.
Houses are constantly going underwater, with farmland turning unusable due to inundation by seawater and increasing soil salinity.
Oceanographers predict Ghoramara will vanish underwater in 2050, but local residents believe the island will be destroyed in the next 10-15 years.
writtenSummary:

title: UK could take legal action against France over fishing row
writtenTitle: UK could take legal action against France over fishing row
summary:
The UK is prepared to take legal action against France over the ongoing row about post-Brexit fishing rights, the Foreign Secretary said.
Last month, the UK and Jersey denied permits to dozens of French boats to operate in their waters.
In retaliation, France threatened to block British boats from some of its ports and cut electricity to Jersey.
writtenSummary:
The UK is prepared to take legal action against France over the ongoing row about post-Brexit fishing rights, the Foreign Secretary said.
Last month, the UK and Jersey denied permits to dozens of French boats to operate in their waters.
In retaliation, France threatened to block British boats from some of its ports and cut electricity to Jersey.

title: Covid booster jabs available at walk-in sites in England
writtenTitle: Covid booster jabs available at walk-in sites in England
summary:
Booster jabs against Covid are now available at walk-in sites in England as the NHS hopes to bolster uptake ahead of a "challenging" winter.
About 30 million people who had their second vaccination over 6 months ago will be able to get a booster without an appointment.
The NHS online walk-in finder will let people check their nearest centre.
writtenSummary:
Booster jabs against Covid are now available at walk-in sites in England as the NHS hopes to bolster uptake ahead of a "challenging" winter.
About 30m people who had their second vaccination over 6 months ago will be able to get a booster without an appointment.
The NHS online walk-in finder will let people check their nearest centre.

title: Around 41% of Shiba Inu's total supply is burned
writtenTitle: Around 41% of Shiba Inu's total supply is burned
summary:
About 41% of the token's total supply is burned - meaning those coins are not in circulation anymore, data by Etherscan showed.
Shiba Inu is an Ethereum-based alternative to dogecoin founded in 2020 by someone going by the name Ryoshi.
Its unlikely rise has catapulted the meme-inspired cryptocurrency to a total market valuation of nearly $37 billion.

About 41% of the token's total supply is burned - meaning those coins are not in circulation anymore, data by Etherscan showed.

title: Nightclubs reopen in Northern Ireland
writtenTitle: Covid-19: Nightclubs reopen in Northern Ireland
summary:
Nightclubs in Northern Ireland reopened on Sunday as some remaining coronavirus restrictions imposed last March were lifted.
The hospitality sector is expected to be busy on Halloween night, with legal requirements on social distancing also being scrapped.
Ministers want people to be sensible and exercise personal responsibility as they step out.
writtenSummary:
Nightclubs in Northern Ireland reopened on Sunday as some remaining coronavirus restrictions imposed last March were lifted.
The hospitality sector is expected to be busy on Halloween night, with legal requirements on social distancing also being scrapped.
Ministers want people to be sensible and exercise personal responsibility as they step out.

title: Facebook wants children as young as 6 to be its customers
writtenTitle: Facebook wants children as young as 6 to be its customers
summary:
An internal blog post has revealed Facebook wants to cross the COPPA threshold.
New documents accessed by NBC News have revealed that Facebook actively hired employees to build products for children as young as 6 years to expand its user base.
The company has been under the scanner since whistleblower Frances Haugen leaked internal documents.
writtenSummary:
An internal blog post has revealed Facebook wants to cross the COPPA threshold. 
New documents accessed by NBC News have revealed that Facebook actively hired employees to build products for children as young as 6 years to expand its user base. 
The company has been under the scanner since whistleblower Frances Haugen leaked internal documents.

title: 57% of tech execs say labour shortage has become their biggest concern
writtenTitle: 57% of tech execs say labour shortage has become their biggest concern
summary:
Finding the right employees has risen to become the top concern among tech executives, amid the ongoing labour shortage, according to polling data from CNBC.
For 26% of the respondents, supply chain issues were the highest worry.
About 70% of tech companies had expanded their searches for job applicants by adding more roles for remote workers.
writtenSummary:
Finding the right employees has risen to become the top concern among tech executives, amid the ongoing labour shortage, according to polling data from CNBC.
For 26% of the respondents, supply chain issues were the highest worry.
About 70% of tech companies had expanded their searches for job applicants by adding more roles for remote workers.

title: Meghan Markle buys £18 coffee vouchers for every worker at charity
writtenTitle: Meghan Markle buys £18 coffee vouchers for every worker at charity
summary:
Meghan sent the "classy" gesture to those working to pass landmark legislation that would introduce paid parental leave in the US for the first time.
The US is one of the few countries in the world that doesn’t guarantee paid sick leave or maternity or paternity pay.
Meghan said she was "overwhelmed" after the birth of their second child, Lilibet.

title: 2 dead, hundreds evacuated after pipeline explosion in South Africa
writtenTitle: 2 dead, hundreds evacuated after pipeline explosion in South Africa
summary:
Two people died and hundreds evacuated after an underground pipeline in Durban caught fire forcing hundreds of local residents to flee their homes.
It is alleged that three people were involved in a botched fuel theft attempt leading to a fire outbreak.
Local security company Security Force said several people suffered smoke inhalation.
writtenSummary:
Two people died and hundreds evacuated after an underground pipeline in Durban caught fire forcing hundreds of local residents to flee their homes.
It is alleged the three people were involved in a botched fuel theft attempt leading to a fire outbreak.
Local security company Security Force said several people suffered smoke inhalation.

title: France has 48 hours to back down in fishing row, warns Liz Truss
writtenTitle: France has 48 hours to back down in fishing row, warns Liz Truss
summary:
The UK foreign secretary Truss warned France it has 48 hrs to back down on threats made in the row over fishing licences or Britain will begin dispute talks set out in the Brexit deal.
The UK has allocated 98% of EU fishing licences to EU vessels.
France has threatened to bar UK boats and tighten customs checks on lorries entering the country.
writtenSummary:
The UK foreign secretary Truss warned France it has 48 hrs to back down on threats made in the row over fishing licences or Britain will begin dispute talks set out in the Brexit deal.
The UK has allocated 98% of EU fishing licences to EU vessels.
France has threatened to bar UK boats and tighten customs checks on lorries entering the country.

title: Japan election: PM Fumio Kishida declares victory for ruling LDP
writtenTitle: Japan election: PM Fumio Kishida declares victory for ruling LDP
summary:
Japan's ruling coalition celebrated holding on to a strong majority in the elections, with PM Kishida hailing the results as a big deal for trust.
The coalition won 293 of the 465 seats in the lower house of the parliament.
Tokyo Investors cheered news that Kishida's long-ruling Liberal Democratic Party and its coalition partner Komeito had won.
writtenSummary:
Japan's ruling coalition celebrated holding on to a strong majority in the elections, with PM Kishida hailing the results as a big deal for trust.
The coalition won 293 of the 465 seats in the lower house of the parliament.
Tokyo Investors cheered news that Kishida's long-ruling Liberal Democratic Party and its coalition partner Komeito had won.

title: Africa: Migrants desperate for help camp on UN's doorstep
writtenTitle: Africa: Migrants desperate for help camp on UN's doorstep
summary:
Up to 3,000 migrants and refugees have spent the past month camped out on the streets of Libya's capital, Tripoli, outside a community centre run by the United Nations.
Many are desperate for help, after fleeing overcrowded detention centres.
During one mass escape last month, six migrants were killed when guards opened fire.
writtenSummary:
Up to 3,000 migrants and refugees have spent the past month camped out on the streets of Libya's capital, Tripoli, outside a community centre run by the United Nations.
Many are desperate for help, after fleeing overcrowded detention centres.
During one mass escape last month, six migrants were killed when guards opened fire.

title: Rights group urge Indonesian govt to investigate shooting of children
writtenTitle: Rights group urge Indonesian govt to investigate shooting of children
summary:
Two children were shot during a gunfight between armed groups and Indonesian security forces in Intan Jaya regency, Papua province.
The sources said they believed the shots that struck the victims came from a nearby military command post.
Amnesty urged the govt to effectively investigate the death of one child and the injury to another.
writtenSummary:
Two children were shot during a gunfight between armed groups and Indonesian security forces in Intan Jaya regency, Papua province.
The sources said they believed the shots that struck the victims came from a nearby military command post.
Amnesty urged the govt to effectively investigate the death of one child and the injury to another.

title: PM Johnson: Get serious about climate change or it will be too late
writtenTitle: "Get serious about climate change or it will be too late" PM Johnson
summary:
"If we don't get serious about climate change today, it will be too late for our children to do so tomorrow," PM Boris Johnson told leaders at the COP26 summit.
He said the conference at Glasgow must mark the beginning of the end of climate change.
Johnson warned that time was running out - the longer we fail to act, the worse it gets.
writtenSummary:
"If we don't get serious about climate change today, it will be too late for our children to do so tomorrow," PM Boris Johnson opened the COP26 summit.
He was speaking to leaders from 120 countries ahead of tense talks.
"If summits alone solve climate change then we wouldn't have needed 25 previous COP summits to get where we are today,” PM said.

title: France protects bookshops from Amazon´s "distorted competition"
writtenTitle: France protects bookshops from Amazon´s "distorted competition"
summary:
France will set a minimum price for book deliveries, in an effort to help bookshops compete with tech giants.
More than 20% of the 435m books sold in France in 2019 were bought online.
The government says Amazon creates “distorted competition”, however, Amazon pushed back saying the new legislation would impact readers, small towns and rural areas.
writtenSummary:
France will set a minimum price for book deliveries. The move is to help bookshops compete with tech giants. 
More than 20% of the 435m books sold in France in 2019 were bought online.
The government says Amazon creates “distorted competition”. Amazon pushed back saying the new legislation would impact readers, small towns, and rural areas.

title: One in four in England not complying with Covid self-isolation
writtenTitle: One in four in England not complying with Covid self-isolation
summary:
The number of people who are no longer following the full rules around self-isolation after a positive Covid test has increased.
The ONS estimates that 78% of individuals who have a positive Covid test follow the full requirements for self-isolation.
The ONS said the compliance rate was “significantly lower” than levels seen earlier in the year.
writtenSummary:
The number of people who are no longer following the full rules around self-isolation after a positive Covid test has increased.

title: Here’s how much progress the UK has made on 3 key net-zero pledges
writtenTitle: Here’s how much progress the UK has made on three key net-zero pledges
summary:
There are lots of hurdles which the UK must overcome to achieve its own 100% EV sales target by 2030.
The UK has pledged to phase out petrol and diesel car sales by 2030, stop burning coal to generate energy by 2024.
Another target is to ensure all heating systems are low-carbon by 2035. While advancements have been made, targets are still off mark.
writtenSummary:
Experts answered how the UK is really progressing to net zero emissions by 2050 going.
The UK has pledged to phase out petrol and diesel car sales by 2030, stop burning coal to generate energy by 2024. 
Another target is to ensure all heating systems are low-carbon by 2035. While advancements have been made, targets are still off mark.

title: Ryanair set to cut winter fares to boost demand
writtenTitle: Ryanair set to cut winter fares to boost demand
summary:
Ryanair says it is expecting to cut fares this winter to help boost passenger demand.
The airline has seen business picking up recently, but warns it is still recovering from the Covid-related collapse in air travel.
The carrier reported an after-tax loss of €48m for the six months to September, which compared with a loss after tax of €411m in 2020.
writtenSummary:
Ryanair says it is expecting to cut fares this winter to help boost passenger demand.
The airline has seen business picking up recently, but warns it is still recovering from the Covid-related collapse in air travel.
The carrier reported an after-tax loss of €48m for the six months to September, which compared with a loss after tax of €411m in 2020.

writtenTitle: Brexit wars: Why France and UK get so angry about access to the sea
summary:
A dispute between Britain and France about fishing territories has escalated rapidly.
The wider issue here is the licences now required under the new Brexit arrangements; French and UK fishing boats have both reported tensions.
Since the early 1600s and throughout history France and the UK have had rows over sea access.

title: Aukus: French president says Australian PM lied over submarine deal
writtenTitle: Aukus: French president says Australian PM lied over submarine deal
summary:
French President Emmanuel Macron said Australia's PM Scott Morrison lied to him about a scrapped submarine deal.
Macron was furious after Australia cancelled a $37bn (£27bn) deal to build 12 submarines, and instead negotiated a new defence pact with the US and the UK - the so-called Aukus.
However, Morrison denies that he was dishonest.
writtenSummary:
French President Emmanuel Macron has said Australia's PM Scott Morrison lied to him about a scrapped submarine deal.
Mr Macron was furious after Australia cancelled a $37bn (£27bn) deal to build 12 submarines, and instead negotiated a new defence pact with the US and the UK - the so-called Aukus.
Mr Morrison denies that he was dishonest.

writtenTitle: Afghanistan: Victims' families decry glorification of suicide bombers
summary:
A recent event to "honor" the Taliban's suicide bombers and their "sacrifices" has drawn heavy criticism from Afghans.
The Kabul ceremony to honor suicide bombers not only offended the victims' families but also drew wide-ranging criticism on Afghanistan's social media.
The Shiite Hazara community has been the worst victim of suicide bombings.

The incident comes with the topic of legalising cannabis taking the front stage in Germany.

title: Amazon is launching its first internet satellites next year
writtenTitle: Amazon is launching its first internet satellites next year
summary:
By 2022, Amazon will launch the first satellites for Project Kuiper, a broadband service that will beam internet down from space.
Project Kuiper constellation will eventually comprise 3,236 satellites.
Satellite internet providers like Project Kuiper and Starlink aim to provide high-speed internet to places poorly served by current infrastructure.

By 2022, Amazon will launch the first satellites for Project Kuiper, a broadband service that will beam internet down from space. 
Project Kuiper constellation will eventually comprise 3,236 satellites. 
Satellite internet providers like Project Kuiper and Starlink aim to provide high-speed internet to places poorly served by current infrastructure.

title: TikTok's owner is countering China's "996" work culture, reports say
writtenTitle: TikTok's owner is countering China's "996" work culture, reports say
summary:
TikTok's owner ByteDance has reportedly instructed employees in China to finish work no later than 7 pm on weekdays.
Chinese companies are known for making staff work from 9 am to 9 pm six days a week - otherwise called the 996 work schedule.
ByteDance's new policy comes after criticism of the 996 schedule for making work-life balance difficult.
writtenSummary:

ByteDance's new policy comes after criticism of the 996 schedule for making work-life balance difficult.

writtenTitle: Mark Zuckerberg's Meta logo looks a lot like Berlin-based migraine app
summary:
M-sense Migräne, a migraine app developed by Newsenselab, has taken a dig at Meta as the social media giant’s logo seems to be heavily inspired by the app.
Health startup M-sense Migräne offers digital treatment programs for people suffering from migraines and headaches.
It looks like M-sense is not looking to take any legal action against Facebook.

writtenTitle: Squid Game cryptocurrency trading at $0, scammers make $2.1 million
summary:
Scammers behind the cryptocurrency that peaked at $2,861 before plummeting to $0 on Monday made over $2.1 mn before shutting the crypto project.
The developers don't want to continue running the project due to the stress of dealing with scammers.
The latest development shows how risky it can be to invest in a new and hyped token in the crypto market.

title: "Vax" chosen as word of the year by Oxford English Dictionary firm
writtenTitle: "Vax" chosen as word of the year by Oxford English Dictionary firm
summary:
In September usage of the word was up more than 72 times from its level last year.
The use of vax in combination phrases such as fully-vaxxed partly accounted for the big increase in its popularity.
Dr Durham from Cardiff University said social media were likely to have an impact, meaning words devised by younger generations now had more of a reach.

The use of vax in combination phrases such as fully-vaxxed partly accounted for the big increase in its popularity.

title: Germany: Human rights groups file complaint against Belarus officials
writtenTitle: Germany: Human rights groups file complaint against Belarus officials
summary:
A lawsuit has been filed against a group of Belarus security officials for crimes against humanity.
They were accused of carrying out mass detentions, torture, sexual violence and political persecution.
The lawsuit was filed in German court due to its principle of universal jurisdiction, which can prosecute crimes committed anywhere in the world.
writtenSummary:
A lawsuit has been filed against a group of Belarus security officials for crimes against humanity.
They were accused of carrying out mass detentions, torture, sexual violence, and political persecution.
The lawsuit was filed in German court due to its principle of universal jurisdiction, which can prosecute crimes committed anywhere in the world.

title: Berlin police apologise for push-ups on Holocaust memorial
writtenTitle: Berlin police apologize for push-ups on Holocaust memorial
summary:
The head of police condemned officers after images emerged of them doing push-ups on the blocks that make up the Holocaust memorial.
A newspaper published photos of officers in uniform and carrying weapons using the memorial's concrete blocks for exercise.
The Memorial to the Murdered Jews of Europe consists of  2,711 grey blocks in Berlin.
writtenSummary:
The head of police condemned officers after images emerged of them doing push-ups on the blocks that make up the Holocaust memorial.
A newspaper published photos of officers in uniform and carrying weapons using the memorial's concrete blocks for exercise.
The Memorial to the Murdered Jews of Europe consists of  2,711 grey blocks in Berlin.

title: Macron delays retaliation in France-UK fishing row to allow talks

France is demanding more permits to fish in British waters under the UK-EU trade deal.
The UK government did not immediately comment on Macron's offer.

Thunberg was one of the environmental activists speaking at the "Fridays for Future" meeting near the COP26 campus.

title: Nigeria: Many feared trapped in Lagos building collapse
writtenTitle: Nigeria: Many feared trapped in Lagos building collapse
summary:
A 25-story building under construction collapsed by Musliu Junction, Ikoyi in Nigeria's economic capital - Lagos.
Officials could not say how many people were trapped, but workers and neighbours were scrambling to pull people from the rubble.
According to local residents, dozens of people were inside when the building collapsed.

writtenTitle: Sudan's ousted prime minister Abdalla Hamdok calls for reinstatement
summary:
Sudan's ousted PM Hamdok says the reinstatement of his govt, dissolved in a military coup, could pave the way to a solution in the country.
The information ministry said PM spoke with ambassadors of the US, UK and Norway at his home, where he is under house arrest.
Several people staged a demonstration on Saturday against the army's power grab.

title: Algeria to halt gas exports to Spain via Morocco
writtenTitle: Algeria to halt gas exports to Spain via Morocco
summary:
President Tebboune ordered state energy firm Sonatrach to halt gas exports to Spain through a pipeline that traverses Morocco due to tensions with Rabat.
Since 1996 the Gaz-Maghreb-Europe (GME) pipeline was used to deliver several billion cubic metres per year to Spain and Portugal.
The GME pipeline contract is due to expire at midnight Sunday.

title: Afghanistan: Deadly explosions hit military hospital in Kabul
writtenTitle: Afghanistan: Deadly explosions hit military hospital in Kabul
summary:
At least 15 people are believed to have been killed and 34 wounded after two explosions followed by gunfire hit the biggest military hospital in Kabul.
There was no immediate claim of responsibility.
But the official Bakhtar news agency quoted witnesses saying a number of Islamic State fighters entered the hospital and clashed with security forces.

Disney World closed its doors and stopped all rides for two days after a single case of Delta was identified.
The park has been reopened but the company is still testing all visitors.

Brazil, where stretches of the Amazon rainforest have been cut down, was among the signatories on Tuesday.
The pledge includes almost £14bn ($19.2bn) of public and private funds.

JCB will take 10% of the green hydrogen made by the Australian firm Fortescue Future Industries (FFI).
FFI said the deal was a "first-of-a-kind partnership" that would see it become the UK's largest supplier of the clean fuel.

title: Archaeologists in Saudi Arabia excavate "forgotten kingdoms"
writtenTitle: Archaeologists in Saudi Arabia excavate "forgotten kingdoms"
summary:
In Al-Ula, archaeologists are working to excavate the remnants of the ancient and long-forgotten kingdoms of Dadan and Lihyan.
Dadan is mentioned in the Old Testament and the Lihyanite kingdom was one of the largest of its time.
Spanning roughly 900 years until 100 CE, the kingdoms controlled vital trade routes but little is known about them.

title: Language "speed dating" brings Jews and Arabs closer
writtenTitle: Language "speed dating" brings Jews and Arabs closer
summary:
Israelis and Palestinians in Jerusalem are trying to bridge a Hebrew-Arabic language gap through learning modelled on speed dating.
Students meet weekly, and sitting together, Jew facing Arab, they practise each other's language.
When a whistle sounds every 20 mins, participants rotate with new partners across tables arranged under colourful murals.

summary:
26 firefighters were on a training exercise in the Duas Bocas cave when its roof collapsed.
Police and emergency health teams had joined firefighters in a desperate effort to free those still trapped, but the work was hampered by heavy rains.
Access to the remote site was difficult, and threats of new collapses complicated the rescue attempts.

China is in the midst of a large-scale crackdown on big tech companies.

Hiding the suffering and deaths of some from public view while showing others creates a value system.
During the past 20 years of the war in Afghanistan, Afghans have been used as rhetorical and visual tools to justify ongoing war in the country.

writtenTitle: Many scientists are atheists, but not anti-religious
summary:
People often view scientists as “Godless" - a view that results from people hearing more from vocal atheist scientists.
In the US, 29% of atheist scientists also say they are culturally religious.
Many atheist scientists think religion can be beneficial to society; atheist scientists and the religious have more in common than most people may think.

summary:

writtenTitle: La Palma volcano: Politician wants to BOMB Canary Island to stop lava
summary:
A Canary Island politician has suggested bombing La Palma's erupting Cumbre Vieja volcano, which has been oozing streams of hot lava for 44 days straight.

summary:
The metaverse is a network of always-on virtual environments in which many people can interact with one another and digital objects while operating virtual representations of themselves.
The metaverse is a concept from science fiction that many people in the technology industry envision as the future.
Facebook is aiming to dominate the metaverse.

Two UK police officers have pleaded guilty to taking and sharing photos of the bodies of two murdered sisters at a crime scene they were assigned to protect.

They admitted committing misconduct in a public office between June 7 and June 23 2020.

The Global Methane Pledge aims to limit methane emissions by 30% compared with 2020 levels.

summary:
The government is unlikely to meet its pledge to increase the number of GPs in England by 6,000 by 2025.
This is because the number of GPs in England is falling, with more GPs opting to go part-time or retire early.
“The stability of the overall GP workforce, the NHS and the health of the UK population as a whole” could be compromised.

Wet wipes containing plastic are piling up across the UK and changing the shape of rivers.
The problem is growing, with the Great British Beach Clean reportedly seeing an increase from 1.7 wet wipes per average 100m of beach to 18 wet wipes between 2005 and 2020.
The government has committed to ending the throwaway culture.

Called the Sphinx, the patch on remote Braeriach melted away more frequently in the last 18 years.

writtenTitle: US: CDC gives final OK for Pfizer Covid vaccine for kids ages 5 to 11
summary:
Vaccinations for young kids are expected to begin immediately, allowing many parents across the US to breathe a sigh of relief.
Pfizer said its clinical trial for kids ages 5 -11 found the shots were well tolerated, with common side effects being mild.
Vaccines will be given to kids in smaller doses, one-third of the dosage given to teens and adults.

title: Facebook to end use of facial recognition software
writtenTitle: Facebook to end use of facial recognition software
summary:
Facebook has decided it will no longer use facial-recognition software to identify faces in photographs and videos.
It said regulators had not yet provided a clear set of rules over how it should be used.
There have been growing concerns about the ethics of facial recognition technology, with questions raised over privacy, racial bias and accuracy.

writtenTitle: 110 journalist killed in DR Congo since the beginning of this year
summary:
The Internation journalist organisation known as the journalist en danger (JED), has alleged 110 journos have been killed in the DR of Congo since Jan 2021.
The organisation calls on Kinshasa to identify the perpetrators so that they can be brought to justice.
They allege that some of the threats come from the militiamen and political militants.

title: Sanatan Shastar Vidya: The ancient Indian battlefield art
writtenTitle: Sanatan Shastar Vidya: The ancient Indian battlefield art
summary:
Sanatan Shastar Vidya is an ancient martial art, which has existed in northern India for thousands of years.
It was adopted by the Sikh warriors in the 17th Century and is considered a spiritual as well as a physical exercise.
Today a modernised version is practiced, as 'Gatka' - which predominantly involves stick fighting and tactical positioning.

title: President Biden admits healthcare is a privilege in US
writtenTitle: President Biden admits Healthcare Is a Privilege in US
summary:
Biden tweeted receiving health care should be a right, not a privilege, and urged citizens to get a health plan by 2022.
Some argued that if health was a right, they should not pay to have access to it.
His social investment plan included issues such as lowering drug prices and dental and vision coverage for Medicaid insurance program beneficiaries.

The UK is recording very high levels of coronavirus, with 33,865 cases recorded on Tuesday, 2 November.
Deaths are rising, with 293 deaths within 28 days of a positive test.

title: How China Is Saving the Giant Panda - A Three-Pronged Approach
writtenTitle: How China Is Saving the Giant Panda - A Three-Pronged Approach
summary:
One of the biggest reasons endangering giant pandas was disappearing habitat.
In 1980s, much of the bamboo on the their main habitat area died and a handful of starving giant pandas were rescued to Chengdu Zoo.
Their protection has been three-pronged since then: protecting their habitat, captive breeding, and introducing laws to stop panda hunting.
writtenSummary:
The most important work to save the giant panda is protecting their habitat. Without this, pandas could only survive in captivity.
There are several panda centers in China to breed pandas, educate people about protecting pandas, and to do research.
China's government established laws and severe penalties to protect them from hunting and smuggling.

title: "Secretive court system threatens Paris deal," whistleblower says
writtenTitle: "Secretive court system threatens Paris deal," Whistleblower says
summary:
A secretive investor court system poses a real threat to the Paris climate agreement, activists have said.
New data seen by the Guardian shows a surge in cases under the energy charter treaty (ECT).
ECT is an obscure international agreement that allows energy corporations to sue governments over policies that could hurt their profits.

New data seen by the Guardian shows a surge in cases under the energy charter treaty (ECT). 
ECT is an obscure international agreement that allows energy corporations to sue governments over policies that could hurt their profits.

writtenTitle: Israeli spyware company NSO Group placed on US blacklist
summary:

NSO denies accusations.

title: Preventing future pandemics: Environment, humans and animals
writtenTitle: Preventing future pandemics: Environment, humans and animals
summary:
The Covid-19 pandemic has demonstrated that zoonotic diseases, infections that pass from animals to humans, present threats to global health.
More than 70% of emerging pathogens originate from animals.
The health of animals, people and the environment is closely connected, and factors that affect one can affect all.

More than 70% of emerging pathogens originate from animals.

title: Brain sensors find why humans get taller
writtenTitle: Brain sensors find why humans get taller
summary:
The puzzle of why humans are growing taller and reaching puberty earlier than ever before can be explained by a sensor in the brain, scientists say.
Average height in the UK rose by 3.9in (10cm) during the 20th Century, and up to 7.8in in other countries, as nutritional health improved.
But exactly how this happens has never been understood.

But exactly how this happens has never been understood.

title: India cuts fuel taxes as prices hit record highs
writtenTitle: India cuts fuel taxes as prices hit record highs
summary:
India has cut the taxes paid by consumers on petrol and diesel after the surging cost of crude oil pushed fuel prices to record highs.
The decision aims to ease price rises and "further spur the overall economic cycle", the government said.
Global commodity prices have soared this year as economies around the world recover from the pandemic.

title: HPV vaccine cutting cervical cancer by nearly 90%
writtenTitle: HPV vaccine cutting cervical cancer by nearly 90%
summary:
The human papillomavirus, or HPV, vaccine is cutting cases of cervical cancer by nearly 90%, the first real-world data shows.
Cancer Research UK described the findings as "historic", and said it showed the vaccine was saving lives.
Nearly all cervical cancers are caused by viruses, and the hope is that vaccination could almost eliminate the disease.

The human papillomavirus, or HPV, vaccine is cutting cases of cervical cancer by nearly 90%, the first real-world data shows.
Cancer Research UK described the findings as "historic", and said it showed the vaccine was saving lives.
Nearly all cervical cancers are caused by viruses, and the hope is vaccination could almost eliminate the disease.

title: Human species who lived 500,000 years ago named Homo bodoensis
writtenTitle: Human species who lived 500,000 years ago named Homo bodoensis
summary:
The species lived in Africa about 500,000 years ago, during the Middle Pleistocene age, and was the direct ancestor of modern humans.
The epoch is significant because it was when anatomically contemporary humans, Homo sapiens, appeared in Africa and the Neanderthals in Europe.
However, human evolution during this age is poorly understood.
writtenSummary:
The species lived in Africa about 500,000 years ago, during the Middle Pleistocene age, and was the direct ancestor of modern humans.

However, human evolution during this age is poorly understood.

title: Honeybees use social distancing when mites threaten hives
writtenTitle: Honeybees use social distancing when mites threaten hives
summary:
When a hive of honeybees is under threat from mites, the bees respond by changing the way they interact with one another.
Foraging bees, which tend to be older members of the colony, keep away from the centre of the colony where the young bees, the queen and brood cells are found.
That may help to keep the infection at a level that can be controlled.
writtenSummary:
