title: Plant in traditional Samoa medicine could be as effective as ibuprofen
writtenTitle: Plant in traditional Samoa medicine could be as effective as ibuprofen
summary:
Leaves of the matalafi plant could be as effective as ibuprofen in lowering inflammation and could even be used to treat illnesses such as Parkinson’s and cancer.
The leaves could also potentially be used to treat diabetes, cardiovascular diseases as well as Covid-19.
There is a lot of scepticism and hesitancy shown toward traditional medicine.

title: Europe’s record summer "impossible" without global heating
writtenTitle: Analysis: Europe’s record summer "impossible" without global heating
summary:
The heatwaves and wildfires that caused devastation in Europe this summer would not have happened without global heating.
The summer of 2021 was the hottest on record in the continent.
If countries do not achieve drastic reductions in emissions by 2030 and hit net zero by 2050, the record heat of 2021 will strike every year by the end of the century.
writtenSummary:
The heatwaves and wildfires that caused devastation in Europe this summer would not have happened without global heating.
The summer of 2021 was the hottest on record in the continent.
If countries do not achieve drastic reductions in emissions by 2030 and hit net zero by 2050, the record heat of 2021 will strike every year by the end of the century.

title: Nasa delays SpaceX launch to ISS over "medical issue" with astronaut
writtenTitle: Nasa delays SpaceX launch to ISS over "medical issue" with astronaut
summary:
"The issue is not a medical emergency and not related to Covid-19", Nasa said.
The launch, originally set for Sunday but then postponed until Wednesday because of unsuitable weather conditions, has been rescheduled for Saturday.
It is the first such delay by Nasa since 1990 when the mission commander of Space Shuttle Atlantis fell ill.
writtenSummary:
"The issue is not a medical emergency and not related to COVID-19", the space agency said. 
The launch, originally set for Sunday but then postponed until Wednesday because of unsuitable weather conditions, has been rescheduled for Saturday.

writtenTitle: US lawmakers introduce Deepavali Day Act

Congresswoman Carolyn B Maloney said Diwali this year symbolises the nation's continuing journey out of the darkness of Covid.
The House Foreign Affairs Committee will be supporting the bill.

writtenTitle: Vandalism of LGBT artwork is hate crime, say Merseyside police

title: Insulate Britain blocks roads around Parliament
writtenTitle: Insulate Britain blocks roads around Parliament
summary:

The group said more than 60 activists had gathered at Bridge Street by Westminster Bridge and the peers' entrance to the Houses of Parliament.
"We have exposed the government's refusal to act on home insulation as cowardly and vindictive," the group says.

The group said more than 60 activists had gathered at Bridge Street by Westminster Bridge and the peers' entrance to the Houses of Parliament.
"We have exposed the government's refusal to act on home insulation as cowardly and vindictive," the group says.

title: "Big Tech bosses could face criminal cases", UK minister says
writtenTitle: "Big Tech bosses could face criminal cases", UK minister says
summary:
Mark Zuckerberg and other tech executives could face the threat of criminal prosecution if they do not tackle harmful algorithms, the UK culture secretary warned.
If they don't, they will be liable for prosecution.
Nadine Dorries also said internet trolls who threaten “serious harm” or post harmful misinformation could face jail sentences.

title: Europe once again at centre of Covid pandemic, says WHO
writtenTitle: Europe once again at centre of Covid pandemic, says WHO
summary:
Vaccines are doing what was promised: preventing severe forms of the disease and mortality, but should be used alongside social measures.
The most alarming development is the rapid increase in infections and deaths in older population groups.
Countries that had mostly lifted preventive measures had experienced a surge in infections.

title: Half world’s fossil fuel assets could become worthless by 2036
writtenTitle: Half world’s fossil fuel assets could become worthless by 2036
summary:
About half of the world’s fossil fuel assets will be worthless by 2036 under a net zero transition, according to research.
Countries that are slow to decarbonise will suffer but early movers will profit.
The study finds that renewables and freed-up investment will more than make up for the losses to the global economy.

writtenTitle: Cop26 protesters urge Sturgeon to act over ‘intimidating’ policing
summary:
Climate campaigners are urging Nicola Sturgeon to intervene in what they describe as intimidating and heavy-handed policing of protests.
Activists reported “numerous incidents of abuse of powers and intimidating tactics”.
Scotland Police had to apologise to women in Glasgow who had to walk home in darkness after well-lit streets were blocked off.

title: UK: First country in the world to approve oral antiviral pill
writtenTitle: UK is first to approve oral antiviral pill to treat Covid
summary:
The MHRA has approved an oral antiviral pill for Covid.
The pill, Lagevrio, can be taken twice daily at home and will be given as a priority to those with vulnerabilities.
The drug is approved for people with mild to moderate Covid and at least one risk factor for developing severe illness, such as obesity, heart disease, or being older than 60.

title: Majority of Germans in favour of mandatory Covid-19 vaccine
writtenTitle: Majority of Germans in favour of mandatory COVID-19 vaccine
summary:
A new Deutschlandtrend survey revealed that some 57% of Germans want Covid vaccines to be made mandatory for people over the age of 18.
74% believe that people in certain professions, particularly in medical, health and other care work, should be required to get the vaccine.
The German government still opposes such a measure.
writtenSummary:
A new Deutschlandtrend survey revealed that some 57% of Germans want COVID vaccines to be made mandatory for people over the age of 18.
74% believe that people in certain professions, particularly in medical, health and other care work, should be required to get the vaccine
The German government still opposes such a measure.

title: Germany Covid cases hit record daily high
writtenTitle: COVID: Germany cases hit record daily high
summary:
Germany registered a record number of Covid-19 cases on Thursday, breaking a record set in December 2020.
The news came a day after Health Minister Spahn said that the fourth wave of the virus was "in full force" across the country.
The number of intensive care beds filled up, largely populated by the unvaccinated.
writtenSummary:
Germany registered a record number of COVID-19 cases on Thursday, breaking a record set in December 2020.

The number of intensive care beds filled up, largely populated by the unvaccinated.

writtenTitle: US: Republicans want billions for Taiwan military aid to counter China
summary:

While the bill is sponsored only by Republicans, it adds to pressure from Congress on Biden for action to strengthen ties with Taiwan.
The US is the main military supplier for Taiwan.

writtenTitle: Italian nun appointed by Pope as first ever female Vatican governor
summary:
Sister Raffaella Petrini will serve as secretary-general of the Governorate and become the highest-ranking woman in the world's smallest state.
Her new role similar to the deputy mayor of a city is traditionally held by a bishop.
Pope Francis has said he wants women to play a bigger role in the Catholic Church to achieve greater gender equality.

title: Sweden: Magdalena Andersson set to become first female Prime Minister
writtenTitle: Sweden: Magdalena Andersson set to become first female Prime Minister
summary:
The country's FM Magdalena Andersson has been unanimously elected as the new leader of Sweden's Social Democrats party.
She is set to become the first female PM in Sweden, provided she wins a vote in parliament.
Her election in the position comes five months after PM Stefan Lofven resigned after losing a vote of confidence in parliament.

writtenTitle: Council of Europe removes hijab campaign images amid backlash
summary:
The Council of Europe has withdrawn social media posts promoting diversity and freedom to wear the hijab.
Posters featuring young women wearing Islamic headscarves were removed from Twitter just days after the project's launch.
The campaign prompted a strong backlash from senior French politicians over secular values.

title: Africa: Statelessness is still a reality
writtenTitle: Africa: Statelessness is still a reality
summary:
Many without a birth certificate are at risk of statelessness and there are at least 1 million such people in West Africa.
It is impossible for them to exercise their fundamental rights such as education, health care and employment.
These people find themselves marginalised, discriminated against and particularly vulnerable to exploitation and abuse.
writtenSummary:

title: Sudanese army announces formation of a new government
writtenTitle: Sudanese army announces formation of a new government
summary:
Sudan army announced a new govt, ten days after the coup d'état of General Al-Burhane, a move condemned by the international community.
Burhane dissolved the govt on 25 Oct, arrested civilian leaders and declared a state of emergency in the country.
Diplomats, academics and journalists are trying to mediate, but so far without much success.

title: As winter looms, reports of starvation in North Korea
writtenTitle: As winter looms, reports of starvation in North Korea
summary:
Defectors based in South Korea say that their families in North Korea are going hungry.
There is a concern as winter approaches that the most vulnerable will starve, especially and the lower classes are suffering more.
North Korea has always struggled with food shortages, but the pandemic has made the bad situation worse.
writtenSummary:
Defectors based in South Korea say that their families in North Korea are going hungry.
There is a concern as winter approaches that the most vulnerable will starve, especially and the lower classes are suffering more and more.

title: UK minister on Kenyan woman's killing controversy
writtenTitle: UK minister on Kenyan woman's killing controversy
summary:
The alleged murder of a Kenyan woman Agnes Wanjiru in 2012 by a British soldier has "let down the British Armed Forces".
The UK Minister for the Armed Forces James Heappey said he believes it is possible to meet with Kenyan authorities without prejudicing the case.
He added that the UK would aid in the investigations accordingly.

writtenTitle: WHO clears India’s indigenously developed Covaxin for global use
summary:
Covaxin has been granted a WHO emergency use listing, which enables it to be used in countries having bilateral agreements with India.
But, WHO said data on vaccination of pregnant women with Covaxin are insufficient to assess its safety in pregnancy.
India has so far administered 12.14 cr doses of Covaxin across the country.

title: Israeli parliament passes budget, avoids government collapse
writtenTitle: Israeli parliament passes budget, avoids government collapse
summary:
Israel’s parliament has passed a long-awaited key national budget before a deadline that would have triggered fresh elections.
The failure to approve the budget by Nov 14 would have brought down the gov't of Bennett, giving Netanyahu an opportunity for a comeback.
Israel's parliament has approved the budget for the first time in more than 3 years.

title: What's the climate impact of private jets?
writtenTitle: COP26: What's the climate impact of private jets?
summary:
There has been criticism of the number of world leaders who have travelled to COP26 in private jets.
Private jets generally produce significantly more emissions per passenger than commercial flights.
A commercial flight uses more fuel per hour, but it is able to fly more passengers than a private jet and therefore produces fewer emissions per person.
writtenSummary:
There has been criticism of the number of world leaders who have travelled to COP26 in private jets.

title: Talks on reviving 2015 Iran nuclear deal to resume November 29
writtenTitle: Talks on reviving 2015 Iran nuclear deal to resume November 29
summary:
Talks on reviving the nuclear deal will resume on Nov 29, as Western concerns over Tehran's nuclear advances grow.
"We agreed to start the negotiations aiming at removal of unlawful, inhumane sanctions on 29 Nov in Vienna," Iran's top nuclear negotiator Bagheri said.
Negotiations have been on hold since the June election of Iranian President Raisi.

title: Biden administration approves $650 million weapon sale to Saudi Arabia
writtenTitle: Biden administration approves $650 million weapon sale to Saudi Arabia
summary:
The US has approved a $650 million sale of air-to-air missiles to Saudi Arabia, in what would be the Biden administration’s first major weapons deal with the Gulf kingdom.
The US approved the sale to help Riyadh counter current and future threats.
Biden announced an end to US support for offensive Saudi-led military operations in Yemen in February.

Cherizier has repeatedly called for the resignation of Prime Minister Henry.

writtenTitle: Yorkshire lose right to host England
summary:

writtenTitle: Thousands of young people to join climate strike
summary:
Thousands of young people are expected to take part in a climate protest in Glasgow in response to COP26.
Pupils taking part will strike from school and march from Kelvingrove Park to the city centre on Friday.
The event is organised by Fridays for Future Scotland, a group founded by young people inspired by the activism of Greta Thunberg.

writtenTitle: Bangladesh removes Islam as state religion to cut tension
summary:
To diffuse religious tensions in the country, the Bangladeshi parliament plans to amend the constitution.
In that they will return to a secular framework, removing Islam as the state religion.
Originally designed to be a secular nation, the Constitution of Bangladesh was meant to establish a state based on a melting pot of liberal culture.

Known on social media as The Sioux Chef, Sherman is reconnecting the denizens of North America with native flavors and ingredients.
They are working to inspire a generation of indigenous chefs to reclaim their culinary past.
A part of their challenge was to cut out colonial ingredients, so they stopped using dairy, wheat flour and cane sugar.

title: Israeli startup develops balloons to capture carbon
writtenTitle: Israeli startup develops balloons to capture carbon
summary:
Removing CO2 from the atmosphere at standard temperatures requires too much energy for governments and companies to consider it cost-effective.
High Hopes Labs has developed a system that captures the carbon where it has almost solidified, far above the Earth.
The frozen carbon then falls back to Earth where it can be recycled for industrial use.

title: US: NYC Mayor-elect vows to take first salary payments in Bitcoin
writtenTitle: NYC Mayor-elect vows to take first salary payments in Bitcoin
summary:
NYC Mayor-elect Eric Adams said he would take his first three paychecks in Bitcoin when he takes over City Hall in January.
Adams has said he wanted to turn New York into a crypto-friendly city and wants to explore an NYC Coin similar to Miami’s.
He vowed to “look at what’s preventing the growth of Bitcoin and cryptocurrency in our city”.
writtenSummary:
NYC Mayor-elect Eric Adams said he would take his first three paychecks in Bitcoin when he takes over City Hall in January. 
Adams has said he wanted to turn New York into a crypto-friendly city and that he wants to explore an NYC Coin similar to Miami’s. 
He vowed to “look at what’s preventing the growth of Bitcoin and cryptocurrency in our city”.

title: Study: Climate misinformation on Facebook "increasing substantially"
writtenTitle: Study: Climate misinformation on Facebook "increasing substantially"
summary:
Researchers found an estimated 45,000 posts downplaying or denying the climate crisis, which have received a combined total of between 818,000 and 1.36 million views.
The study’s release coincides with the COP26 climate summit in Glasgow.
"Our data shows Facebook is among the world’s biggest purveyors of climate disinformation," researchers said.

"Our data shows Facebook is among the world’s biggest purveyors of climate disinformation”, researchers said.

title: Roger McNamee: Democracy at risk if Facebook does not change
writtenTitle: Roger McNamee: Democracy at risk if Facebook does not change
summary:
A former adviser to Zuckerberg said democracy may never recover if Facebook does not change.
He said revelations from Haugen have created an opportunity for change at Zuckerberg’s social media empire.
He repeated a recent demand that the extraction of user data and using it to manipulate consumer behaviour should be made as unethical as child labour.

title: Bank of England sorry for rising cost of living
writtenTitle: Bank of England sorry for rising cost of living
summary:
The Bank of England governor said he is "very sorry" that UK inflation is rising amid forecasts the cost of living could rise 5%.
Bailey said inflation was "something that bites on people's household income."
The Bank will see what impact both domestic and global issues were having on the cost of living before deciding to raise rates.
writtenSummary:
The Bank of England governor has said he is "very sorry" that UK inflation is rising amid forecasts the cost of living could rise 5%.
Mr Bailey said inflation was "something that bites on people's household income."
The Bank will see what impact both domestic and global issues were having on the cost of living before deciding to raise rates.

title: UK: MPs call for inquiry over Boris Johnson's Spanish holiday
writtenTitle: MPs call for inquiry over Boris Johnson's Spanish holiday
summary:
The PM has been criticised for taking free holidays from a friend who is a minister.
The PM declared the trip on the Register of Ministers' Interests, saying he had "a longstanding personal friendship" with the family.
But opposition parties say he should publish details on the Register of Members' Interests covering all MPs.
writtenSummary:

title: Greta Thunberg slams COP26 as a "failure" at youth protest
writtenTitle: Greta Thunberg slams COP26 as a 'failure' at youth protest
summary:
"We don't need any more distant, non-binding pledges. We don't need anymore empty promises," Greta said during a massive youth protest in Glasgow.
Greta assures that the COP is a failure.
New long-term promises include a deforestation commitment, a deal on coal, and a plan to stop investing public finances in foreign fossil fuel.

"We don't need any more distant, non-binding pledges. We don't need anymore empty promises," Greta said during a massive youth protest in Glasgow.

title: Forests can't handle all the COP26 net-zero emissions plans
writtenTitle: Forests can't handle all the COP26 net-zero emissions plans
summary:
Net-zero emissions pledges to protect the climate are coming fast from companies, cities and countries.
Declaring a net-zero target doesn’t mean they plan to stop their greenhouse gas emissions entirely.
Most of these pledges rely heavily on planting trees or protecting forests or farmland to absorb some of their emissions.
writtenSummary:
Net-zero emissions pledges to protect the climate are coming fast and furious from companies, cities and countries
Declaring a net-zero target doesn’t mean they plan to stop their greenhouse gas emissions entirely.
Most of these pledges rely heavily on planting trees or protecting forests or farmland to absorb some of their emissions.

title: US Muslims gave more to charity than other Americans in 2020
writtenTitle: US Muslims gave more to charity than other Americans in 2020
summary:
A study shows that Muslim Americans gave more to charity in 2020 than non-Muslims; they are also more likely to volunteer.
Donations to alleviate the toll Covid-19 has taken on U.S. health, employment and food security comprised 8.8% of Muslim American faith-based giving, versus 5.3% for non-Muslims.
Religion practices were linked to charity works.
writtenSummary:
A study shows that Muslim Americans gave more to charity in 2020 than non-Muslims. They are also more likely to volunteer.
Donations to alleviate the toll COVID-19 has taken on U.S. health, employment and food security comprised 8.8% of Muslim American faith-based giving, versus 5.3% for non-Muslims.
Religion practices were linked to charity works.

title: Police issue alert: ATM scam, Britons see more money cleverly stolen
writtenTitle: Police issue alert: ATM scam, Britons see more money cleverly stolen
summary:
Police are warning people to be vigilant as fraudsters are fitting devices to cash machines to steal money from unsuspecting customers.
The scam has been highlighted by the Metropolitan Police on Twitter after a series of attacks in south London.
The Metropolitan Police advised: “Fraudsters sometimes fit devices to ATMs trapping cards or cash”.

title: Does outer space end?
writtenTitle: Does outer space end? — Gen Z: We Are The Future
summary:
The definition of space has been contested for decades, ever since space exploration started in the mid-20th century.
Some countries argued that a definition was needed, especially because there was an emergence of space programs.
The US stated that there was no need for such a definition, while International Treaties state that space is for all.

title: Haul culture and the environment
writtenTitle: Haul Culture and the Environment — Gen Z: We Are The Future
summary:
The fashion industry is responsible for 10% of all greenhouse gases emitted to the atmosphere.
Greenhouse gases are the main culprit responsible for global warming, it traps gases inside the earth's atmosphere and raises the planet's temperature in return.
Climate change heavily impacts regions in different ways.
writtenSummary:
The fashion industry is responsible for 10% of all greenhouse gases emitted to the atmosphere.
Greenhouse gases are the main culprit responsible for global warming, it traps gases inside the earth's atmosphere and raises the planet's temperature in return.
Climate change heavily impacts regions in different ways: an area could experience drought.
